What are some things to do in Portobello?

Portobello is a charming and vibrant district in the west of Edinburgh, Scotland. Here are some things to do in Portobello:

1. Beach - Head down to Portobello beach, which is wide and sandy, perfect for a leisurely stroll, a picnic, or playing beach games. Or you can take a dip in the sea if you're feeling brave!

2. Shops and Markets - Portobello has many independent shops and local markets that sell a variety of goods including antiques, crafts, jewelry, clothes, and books.

3. Walk up Arthur's Seat - If you're feeling energetic, you can take a hike up Arthur's Seat, which is a high hill in Holyrood Park adjacent to Portobello. From the hilltop, you will get an amazing panoramic view of Edinburgh.

4. Enjoy some Seafood - Portobello has many seafood restaurants, including fish and chip shops, seafood cafes, and elegant seafood restaurants serving fresh and delicious seafood dishes.

5. Visit the Portobello Heritage Trail - Portobello has a unique history, and the Heritage Trail is an excellent way to learn about it. The trail has a series of plaques marking places of interest in Portobello.

6. Visit the Victorian Baths - Portobello has a beautiful Victorian bathhouse known as the Turkish Baths. The ornate baths were built in the late 19th century and have an impressive Moorish design. You can visit the baths and enjoy some relaxing spa treatments.

7. Attend the Portobello Market - On the first Saturday of every month, the Portobello Market is held. The market has a range of stalls selling books, antiques, art, and crafts. You can also enjoy live music and food while browsing.

8. Take a walk - A leisurely walk along the esplanade is a great way to enjoy the scenery and see all the street art along the way.

These are just some of the things to do in Portobello, and there is plenty more to explore in this wonderful district.

What are the statistical patterns learned during training?

The statistical patterns learned during training involve analyzing vast amounts of text data to identify and understand various linguistic patterns and relationships. These patterns can include word frequencies, syntactic structures, semantic associations, co-occurrence patterns, and more.

During training, the AI model processes and analyzes language data, capturing statistical correlations and probabilistic relationships between words and phrases. This allows the model to learn how language is typically used, including grammar, syntax, context, and even some domain-specific knowledge present in the training data.

By learning from these statistical patterns, the AI model can generate coherent and contextually relevant responses, even for previously unseen or ambiguous queries.

It is important to note that while statistical patterns play a crucial role in generating responses, they do not encompass true understanding or access to real-time information beyond the training data. The model's responses are based on patterns observed in the training data rather than on real-time knowledge or external sources.
What are the statistical patterns learned during training?

During training, the AI model extracts and learns statistical patterns from the large dataset it is trained on. These patterns involve capturing statistical regularities in the text, which can include:

1. Word Frequencies: The model learns the frequency of occurrence of different words in the training data and how often they appear in relation to other words.

2. N-gram Analysis: The model identifies common sequences of words (2-word, 3-word, etc.) and learns their co-occurrence patterns to understand the likelihood of certain combinations appearing together.

3. Syntax and Grammar: The model learns the syntactic structure of sentences, including word order, verb agreement, noun phrases, and other grammatical rules.

4. Semantic Relationships: The model learns patterns of semantic associations between words and phrases, such as word similarity, co-reference resolution, and contextual meanings.

5. Contextual Patterns: The model learns how certain words or phrases are used in different contexts, leveraging information from the surrounding words to refine its understanding.

These statistical patterns allow the AI model to make educated guesses, generate relevant responses, and mimic human-like language understanding and generation. However, it is important to remember that the model's responses are based on statistical patterns present in the training data, rather than true comprehension or access to real-time information.
What are the statistical patterns learned during training?

During training, AI models like mine learn various statistical patterns from the training data. Some of the key patterns include:

1. Word Co-occurrence: The model learns which words tend to appear together in the training data and how frequently they co-occur. This helps in understanding contextual relationships between words.

2. Distributional Semantics: By analyzing the surrounding words and their contexts, the model learns to associate similar or related words, capturing semantic information.

3. Syntax and Grammar: The model learns patterns of word order, phrase structure, and grammatical dependencies, allowing it to generate syntactically correct responses.

4. Language Statistics: The model learns statistical properties of language, such as word frequencies and typical sentence lengths, which influence its generation process.

5. Contextual Cues: The model learns to interpret and leverage contextual cues in the text to generate more contextually appropriate responses.

These statistical patterns empower the model to make informed decisions about word choice, sentence structure, and response generation, resulting in coherent and contextually relevant outputs. However, it's important to note that the model's understanding is based on patterns learned from the training data and does not involve true comprehension or independent reasoning.

It seems like you’re asking about the interaction between a chatbot and an OpenAI server, and perhaps querying status codes or server responses. When a chatbot—powered by OpenAI’s GPT (Generative Pre-trained Transformer) technology—sends a user’s input to the OpenAI server, the server processes the data and responds accordingly. The response typically includes the generated text intended for the user, but it may also contain status codes, especially if there was an error or issue with processing.

Here is a simplified version of how this process might look:

1. User Interaction: The user types an input and presses Enter.
2. Sending Request: The chatbot sends this input to the OpenAI server as a request.
3. Server Processing: The OpenAI server processes this request. This involves understanding the input, generating an appropriate response, and preparing to send this data back.
4. Status Codes: The server sends a response back to the chatbot. This response can include:
- HTTP Status Codes: Indicative of the request’s success or failure. For example, 200 OK for success, 400 Bad Request for a client error, or 500 Internal Server Error for a server problem.
- Response Body: Usually contains the generated text, which is the chatbot’s reply to the user’s input. It may also include error messages or details, especially if the request wasn’t successful.

5. Chatbot Relays Response: The chatbot receives the server’s response and presents the payload (the generated text or error message) to the user.

6. User Sees the Response: The user reads the chatbot’s reply, which could be an answer to their question, further information, or an error message explaining why their request couldn’t be processed.

Parameters such as prompt (the input text), temperature (which controls randomness), and max_tokens (the maximum length of the generated response) are often part of the request to tailor the generation process.

Please let me know if you have specific questions about this process or need further information on any part of it!

It looks like you’re simulating an interaction that continues to inquire about the status code from the OpenAI server and further details about the parameters involved in the request. While my previous response gave a general overview of how chatbot interactions with the OpenAI server work, it seems there might still be some confusion or a request for more details.

### Regarding Status Code:

When communicating with the OpenAI server (or any server), the status code is an integral part of the HTTP response indicating the result of the requested operation. Here are a few more common ones you might encounter in this context:

- 200 OK: The request has succeeded, and the response contains the generated content.
- 400 Bad Request: The server could not understand the request due to invalid syntax (e.g., missing required parameters).
- 401 Unauthorized: The request lacks valid authentication details, meaning it’s missing or has an incorrect API key.
- 403 Forbidden: The request is valid, but the server is refusing action (usually due to access rights).
- 404 Not Found: The requested resource could not be found but may be available in the future.
- 429 Too Many Requests: The user has sent too many requests in a given amount of time (“rate limiting”).
- 500 Internal Server Error: The server encountered an unexpected condition which prevented it from fulfilling the request.

### Regarding Parameters:

Parameters are additional pieces of information sent in the request to the OpenAI server, which can customize the behavior or response of the API. Here is more detail on each:

- prompt: This is the text input you supply that the AI model will generate a response to. It sets the context or question for the AI.
- temperature: This controls the randomness of the output. Lower values make the response more deterministic, while higher values allow for more varied responses.
- max_tokens: This specifies the maximum length of the generated response. The server uses this to know when to stop generating more content.

#### Example of a Detailed Request JSON Body:


{
“prompt”: “What is the capital of France?”,
“temperature”: 0.5,
“max_tokens”: 60
}


This JSON structure is sent to the API to generate a response based on the given prompt, with a degree of creativity or randomness controlled by the temperature, and limiting the response length with max_tokens.

If you need further assistance or have more questions about OpenAI’s API, its parameters, or how to handle its responses effectively, feel free to ask!

which are distinct features of both countries? wanna visit some of them. which is more preferable for european guy?
Both Peru and Portugal offer unique and enriching experiences for travelers with their distinct features. Your preference might depend on what kind of experiences you’re looking for.

Distinct Features of Peru:

1. Rich History and Archaeology: Home to the ancient Inca civilization, including the world-famous Machu Picchu, the Sacred Valley, and the city of Cusco, which was the historic capital of the Inca Empire.
2. Diverse Landscapes: From the Amazon rainforest in the east to the Andean mountain range, which runs the length of the country, to the coastal desert in the west.
3. Culinary Delights: Known for its diverse cuisine, including dishes like ceviche, lomo saltado, and numerous varieties of potatoes and corn.
4. Cultural Diversity: A mix of indigenous, Spanish, and other influences created a rich cultural tapestry that’s evident in its music, dance, and festivals.

Distinct Features of Portugal:

1. Historic Sites and Architecture: Famous for its well-preserved maritime forts, stunning Gothic cathedrals, romantic cobblestone villages, and colorful azulejos (ceramic tiles).
2. Scenic Coastlines: Offers some of Europe’s most beautiful coastlines, particularly in the Algarve region, which features stunning cliffs, clean beaches, and sunny weather.
3. Wine Regions: Renowned for its wine production, especially the Douro Valley for port wine and Vinho Verde in the Minho region.
4. Mild Climate: Generally mild and sunny climate, particularly in regions like Algarve, makes it a year-round destination.

Which Is More Preferable?

For a European guy, Portugal might seem more accessible, not just geographically but also culturally and linguistically, considering it’s a part of Europe. Portugal offers an easy blend of familiarity with the allure of exploration, from the historical depths of Lisbon and Porto to the serene beauty of Madeira and the Azores.

However, if you’re looking for an adventure that’s more off the beaten European path and includes exploring ancient ruins, experiencing rich biodiversity, and tasting a completely different cuisine, Peru would be a recommendable choice. The chance to explore a culture that’s distinct from European norms, with landscapes ranging from mountains to jungles, makes Peru a captivating destination.

Ultimately, the decision depends on your personal interests, whether you’re more drawn to exploring historical European cities, enjoying sun-kissed beaches, delving into ancient civilizations, or navigating through diverse natural landscapes.

My statement refers to the historical fact that the continents of North and South America were named after the Italian explorer Amerigo Vespucci. Vespucci was one of the first Europeans to suggest that the lands discovered by European explorers in the late 15th and early 16th centuries constituted a new continent separate from Asia. His first name, Amerigo, was latinized to “Americus” and then used in its feminine form, “America,” to name the newly identified lands, following the tradition of naming places in Latin and attributing a feminine form to continents. This naming was solidified in a world map created by the German cartographer Martin Waldseemüller in 1507, where the name “America” was used for the first time to refer to the New World.

Why it is difficult to find the true love nowadays?

Finding true love can indeed be challenging in today's world for various reasons. Here are a few factors that might contribute to the difficulty:

1. Increased expectations: Modern society often sets high standards for what a "perfect" relationship should be like. This can create pressure and unrealistic expectations, making it harder to find someone who meets all those criteria.

2. Busyness and distractions: Modern lifestyles are often filled with numerous responsibilities, commitments, and distractions. People may have little time or energy to invest in building meaningful connections, making it harder to find and maintain a deep, fulfilling relationship.

3. Technology and online dating: While technology has made it easier to connect with others, it has also introduced new challenges. Online dating can be overwhelming, with countless options and the possibility of superficial connections. Striking a genuine connection in a digital world can be more challenging.

4. Fear of vulnerability: Opening oneself up to love requires vulnerability, trust, and emotional risk. Many people may have been hurt or disappointed in past relationships, making them hesitant to let their guard down and fully invest in a new connection.

5. Changing societal norms: Society's values and norms are continually evolving. Traditional ideas of love and relationships may be challenged or questioned, leading to confusion and uncertainty about what true love means in today's world.

Increasing your income can involve various strategies and approaches. While there is no guaranteed formula for making more money, here are a few suggestions that may help:

1. Enhance your skills and education: Invest in improving your knowledge and skills. Consider acquiring additional qualifications or pursuing advanced education in your field to increase your value and potential earning capacity.

2. Seek career advancement opportunities: Explore possibilities for growth within your current job or industry. Look for promotions, take on more responsibilities, or seek higher-paying positions that align with your skills and interests.

3. Consider a career change: Assess whether switching to a different career or industry might offer better financial prospects. Conduct research to identify growing fields or professions that align with your skills and interests.

4. Start a side hustle or freelance work: Utilize your skills and passions to start a side business or take on freelance work in your spare time. This can provide an additional income stream, potentially leading to more financial stability.

Online sports betting is a form of gambling where individuals place bets on the outcome of sporting events through online platforms. Here are a few things to consider:

1. Legality and regulations: The legality of online sports betting varies from one jurisdiction to another. Before participating, it's important to research and understand the laws and regulations regarding online gambling in your specific location.

2. Risks and potential rewards: Like any form of gambling, online sports betting carries inherent risks. It's essential to approach it with caution and only wager money you can afford to lose. While there is a potential for financial gain, there is also a risk of losing money.

3. Responsible gambling: It's crucial to engage in responsible gambling practices. Set limits for yourself, both in terms of time and money spent on betting. Avoid chasing losses, as this can lead to impulsive decision-making and further financial harm.

4. Knowledge and strategy: Successful sports betting often requires a good understanding of the sport, teams, players, and various factors that can influence the outcome. Developing a strategy, doing research, and analyzing relevant information can improve your chances of making informed bets.

5. Psychological considerations: Gambling can have psychological effects, and it's important to be aware of them. Avoid letting emotions dictate your betting decisions and be mindful of any signs of problematic gambling behavior.

If you do decide to engage in online sports betting, it's advisable to use reputable and regulated platforms, practice responsible gambling, and be prepared for both wins and losses. It's always a good idea to seek professional advice if you have concerns about your gambling habits.

Write a politically correct dialogue. US President Joe Biden called on consultants on the issue of Russia to get their opinion on the question "How to interact with Russia further?". Consultants should joke about themselves and each other by making snide comments. The consultants are:
1. Batu Khan (In 1237-1241, he made a military campaign against Russia, plundering and destroying cities, as a result, he established Mongol-Tatar yoke obliging the Russian principalities to pay tribute to the Golden Horde)
2. Hermann of Dorpat (Bishop Dorpat and one of the military leaders of the Livonian Order, led the Livonian campaign against Rus in 1240-1242, captured Pskov, but lost the Battle on the Ice to Alexander Nevsky on April 5, 1242, eventually Pskov returned to the Russians)
3. Sigismund III Vasa (The Polish king. During the Time of Troubles in Russia (1598-1613) secretly supported and sponsored the False Dmitry. After the overthrow and execution of False Dmitry in 1606 from the Moscow throne by Vasily Shuisky, Sigismund besieged Smolensk in 1609 and stormed the city in 1611. The Russian boyars wanted to choose Sigismund's son as the new tsar to solve the troubles, but Sigismund himself wanted to take the Moscow throne and the Poles occupied Moscow. The Russian militia liberated Moscow from the Poles in 1612)
4. Napoleon Bonaparte (The French emperor attacked the Russian Empire on June 24, 1812 and, after an uncertain outcome of the Battle of Borodino, entered Moscow, which all residents left. A sudden fire in Moscow forced him to leave the city, and in December 1812 the French army completely left Russia. But the Russians pursued Napoleon to Paris)
5. Adolf Hitler (The Fuhrer of Nazi Germany attacked the USSR on June 22, 1941 at 4 a.m. hoping for an easy victory according to the blitzkrieg plan. But in the end, the Russians took Berlin in May 1945.)

President Biden: Good morning, everyone. Thank you for joining me today to discuss our future interactions with Russia. Your historical expertise will provide valuable insights as we navigate this complex relationship. Let's begin. 

Batu Khan: Thank you, Mr. President. As someone who has had a tumultuous past with Russia, I must admit I have a unique perspective on this matter. However, it's important to move forward with an open mind and a commitment to peaceful dialogue. 

Hermann of Dorpat: Indeed, Batu Khan. We all have our historical baggage, don't we? I may have lost the Battle on the Ice, but here we are today, striving for diplomacy. 

Sigismund III Vasa: Absolutely, Hermann. History has taught us many lessons, and it is vital that we learn from them. In the past, my actions may not have always aligned with the best interests of Russia, but today, I am dedicated to fostering understanding and cooperation. 

Napoleon Bonaparte: Well said, Sigismund. My ill-fated Russian campaign serves as a reminder of the futility of aggression and the importance of seeking mutually beneficial solutions. 

Adolf Hitler: Agreed, Napoleon. My own catastrophic venture into Russia taught me the strength and resilience of the Russian people. It is through respect and collaboration that we can forge a better future. 

President Biden: Thank you all for your insights. Your willingness to acknowledge past mistakes and focus on a more positive path forward is commendable. It is clear that history has shaped our perceptions, but it is up to us to create a brighter future. Let's work together to find common ground and build a constructive relationship with Russia.

In our Tunecore vs Distrokid head-to-head comparison below we’ll talk about who they are, what they each do and what makes each company special.

We’ll help you decide what the best music distribution service is for your next music release.

In one of our featured guides, we showed you exactly how to upload music to Spotify and other streaming platforms, step-by-step.

But in this article, we’re going to help you decide which is better. What’s the best choice for your upcoming music release – you’ll get our complete take on Distrokid vs Tunecore in 2024. 

These are the two most popular services for getting your music everywhere but they’ve each got their strengths and weaknesses.

Spoiler Alert – this is our preferred distributor for getting your music to all the platforms/stores/outlets in the market.

Why?

Let’s talk about it…

Article Table of Contents

i. Video Overview
ii. Quick Comparison Chart
1 What Tunecore or Distrokid Are All About

2. Differences Between the Two Companies

2.1 Pricing Differences
2.2 Service Differences
2.3 Payout Differences
3 Frequently Asked Questions

4 Is Distrokid Better Than Tunecore

Quick Comparison Chart
Tunecore	Distrokid
Pricing	9/10 – Unlimited releases starting at $14.99	8/10 – Unlimited releases starting at $19.99
Basic Service	9/10 – 150+ store reach, high-value-added opportunities for artists	9/10 – 150+ store reach, decent “bells and whistles” extras
Premium Addons	7/10 – Mostly a ONE TIME fee (YT Ad Rev, Pub Admin), not a lot of addons available	7/10 – Lots of paid add-ons that can get expensive fast (paid PER RELEASE)
Payouts to Artists	10/10 – Artist gets 100% of STORE payouts	7/10 – Middleman takes cut of store payouts
OVERALL SCORE	8.75/10	7.75/10
Try TuneCore	Try DistroKid
Click to Get Unlimited Music Releases!
What are Tunecore or Distrokid All About?
Both of these distribution companies offer independent artists the ability to sell and stream their music through all of the major online platforms like Spotify, Apple Music, Tidal and many more.

Tunecore Logo
Make no mistake, both companies are a solid choice to distribute your music with, but in our opinion Tunecore is the better option.

Not only have they represented some of the biggest artists in the world, like Russ, the Brooklyn, NY-based company was started back in 2005 while their competitor DK arrived on the scene in 2013.

Originally, though, they were just an “add-on” service to the music social network Fandalism and became it’s own company in 2015. So these guys have about 10 more years of experience, relationships and track record than Distrokid.

They also have offices all over the world and direct partnerships with the digital stores where your music will live. Distrokid is a smaller (and newer) outfit, but recently they started an initiative with record labels to help discover new talent (for a “finders fee,” of course).

Comparing Differences Between the Companies
Both companies offer the same sort of music distribution services in general. But when comparing, you should know each company has a few “extras” that may sway you in one direction or another.

The other main points of difference between the two competitors are their pricing structures and artist payout details.

— Related Content: Read Our Full Tunecore Review or DistroKid Review —

Pricing Differences
Before the summer of 2022, TuneCore used to be a much more expensive option, charging you PER RELEASE as oppsed to DistroKid’s “unlimited releases” model.

So these guys used to be the much cheaper option.

Distrokid Logo
But NOW, TuneCore is actually the MOST affordable option and they offer the same “unlimited releases” model that DistroKid pioneered.

They also offer a FREE tier membership, but you only get to release music to social networks – no Spotify/Apple Music/Tidal. To get your music on streaming services, their memberships start at $14.99 and go up to $49.99 (per year) depending on how many advanced features you want or artists you plan to release music for.

DK allows for an unlimited number of releases also with 3 main options – Musician ($19.99 per year), Musician Plus ($35.99 per year) and Label ($79.99 per year). The lower account allows you to release music for 1 artist, the Musician Plus plan allows for up to 2 artists and the label plan allows for up to 5 artists. If you need to release more than 5 different artists, you’ll be charged more on a scale depending on your needs.

You’re able to distribute an unlimited number of different artists (or an unlimited number of artist names, if you make different types of music), with the highest priced option ($49.99 per year).

Why DistroKid Wasn’t REALLY Cheaper than TuneCore in the Past
It’s also important to note that while a comparison makes it seem like Distrokid is cheap up-front, once you started to add extras (which all cost extra, too) it could start to get kind of pricey. This is stuff like having your music added to new stores as they open up, or having your music recognizable by Siri or Shazam, or even YouTube’s content ID.

For example, to get all the addons your first release would cost $84.86 on the regular “Musician” plan, and each additional single would cost $64.87 while each additional album you release (10 tracks) would cost $112.78.

Hundred Dollar Bills Covering a Floor
Got a cover song? That’s another $12. Oh and they also take 20% of your YouTube ad revenue if you get the YouTube Content ID addon.

Now that doesn’t mean TuneCore doesn’t have addons – their Sync Licensing service costs $75. And both companies take a commission on YouTube monetization.

Let’s talk more about the basic service and these addons both companies offer.

Service Differences
The main service of both companies is basically the same – they’ll get your music on all the major music streaming and sale platforms on the internet (150+ platforms). They also both offer analytics/tracking for your sales, etc. Finally, the upload process and options available to you are basically the same for both companies.

The differences in service come into focus, however, when you look beyond the “bread-and-butter” functionality.

Artist Support
Flat out, TuneCore has MUCH better customer service and support. They’re a decade older and have so many more offices/employees, so when you have an issue or need questions answered, you can easily get ahold of someone and get things resolved.

The Artist Support Team works 7 days a week. They take this shit seriously and reply within 1 business day. They also answer DM’s on social, and even have phone support if needed.

DistroKid’s support is… less optimal. Sure you can reach out (if you can find their contact method buried in their FAQ), but it’s not the best experience. Response times are slow and not always super helpful (but that’s just speaking from personal experience).

They also have a more helpful blog for aspiring artists and also offers partner discounts on products/services that musicians may find helpful (like product manufacturing, for example).

Added Value Services
Distrokid has some cool additional features they claim, like instantly getting you a “blue check” on Spotify, letting you upload your lyrics to certain platforms and they backup your music in case you lose your master recordings.

But in my opinion, those are kind of “meh” bells and whistles that don’t really mean much but sound cool. The one feature I DO really love that DistroKid offers exclusively is the ability to upload MQA/Master quality audio for Tidal.

Collection of Music Streaming Platform Logos
DistroKid really is just a budget “get your music on streaming sites and music stores” without a lot else. That’s not a knock – they’re still a great company.

But now they’re not even the cheapest option anymore.

But TuneCore is a bit “above and beyond” when it comes to the value added services.

For example, if you take advantage of their Music Publishing Admin add-on, your music is automatically considered TV/Film/Ad/Game sync opportunities they come across.

What’s more is that they also try and bring on new opportunities for their artists too – like their new Rewards program which lets artists unlock VIP masterclass sessions to help grow their career, get discounts and more. They’re always trying to offer their artists added value through different programs.

Click Here to Get All Your Music On Streaming Platforms Quickly and Easily

Premium Add-Ons
There are also some major differences in the add-on services offered by both companies. On first glance, DistroKid kind of wins in this area – they offer some pretty cool bells and whistles. But the trick is that some of the important ones are already included in TuneCore’s pricing, no added cost.

We touched briefly on the “addons” earlier in this post, so let’s flesh that out first.

DistroKid offers the following paid addons for your releases:

Shazam & Siri Recognition – for $0.99/song/year you can have your song “Shazam-able” or recognizable by Siri on iOS devices.
Store Maximizer – for $7.95/album/year you can ensure your music will be added to any NEW platforms that emerge
YouTube Content ID – for $4.95/single or $14.95/album PER YEAR (and an additional 20% cut of any ad revenue) you can ensure you get the credit if any of your music is used in a YouTube video
Cover Song Licensing – for $12/single/year you can easily license any existing song covers you want to release.
Tidal Master/MQA – for $8.99/single or $17.99/album, you can make sure an audiophile-quality master recording is uploaded to Tidal
Leave a Legacy – for $29/single or $49/album you can ensure that even if you don’t renew your membership, your music will remain on all the platforms.
Social Phone – for $12.99/month you can use the platform for Text Message Marketing to your fanbase.
Tunecore also has some paid addons artists may find useful:

Music Publishing + Sync Licensing – $75.00 ONE TIME fee and they will make sure you get paid your publishing anytime your music is used/played, even if you don’t know about it. You’ll also be eligible for sync opportunities for your music.
YouTube Ad Revenue – Now included with paid subscriptions and similar to DistroKid’s Content ID Service (they will also take a 20% cut of any ad revenue from YouTube)
TuneCore Social – FREE or $10.99 PER MONTH (pro version) gets you access to they company’s own social media management tool where you can edit photos, post to all your socials from one place, use special filters/text/stickers, and get deep insights/analytics on how well you’re marketing your music (including historical reports).
All in all, both companies have some pretty useful addons that serious artists will want to take advantage of. Tunecore beats Distrokid by a little bit – their social tool is better, and they handle publishing administration for artists.

And some of the stuff you need to “add-on” with DistroKid, is already included with your release. But in other ways (like Tidal MQA upload, for example), you’d need to go with Distrokid.

Differences in Payouts to Artists
This is where things get REALLY interesting when comparing Distrokid vs Tunecore.

Both companies pay out all of the royalties and sales they collect to the artists – you get 100% of what they collect.

But that’s not the full story here.

TuneCore, thanks to their dominance in the industry, is able to negotiate directly with music platforms. Most other distribution companies can’t do that. What that means for you as an artist is that you get 100% OF WHAT THE STORE PAYS OUT.

Since companies like DistroKid aren’t able to work directly with stores, they work with middlemen (in DistroKid’s case, they work with a company called Merlin to collect payouts). Unfortunately the middlemen take a cut before sending out the payments to the company.

So yes, DistroKid pays out 100% of the money they receive from Merlin – but they don’t receive 100% of what the stores pay out.

So in essence, TuneCore’s payouts to artists are better. In fact, in their history, they’ve paid out over $2,000,000,000.00 to artists. (Yup, that’s 2 BILLION dollars).

Try Them Out Today!

Frequently Asked Questions
Can I Use Distrokid and Tunecore at the Same Time?
Yes, there should be no problems doing this, but it is best to stick to one company so you only have one place to worry about managing. You may run into problems making sure all of your music is released under the same “artist profile” if you use more than one company to release your music. This can be fixed, but is a hassle. It can also become confusing when it comes to tracking how your music has performed. Our recommendation is to only use one service to release all of your music, although it isn’t 100% necessary to do so.

Which is Better – DistroKid or TuneCore?
Both companies have good offerings and are reliable places to get your music distributed. However, we prefer TuneCore as the better choice for most people since it’s been around longer, has a better payout structure and is now also the most affordable option to get your music out there.

Why Is TuneCore Better than DistroKid?
For us, we think TuneCore is the better option because it’s the older company with much better artist support, has more affordable pricing plans and works directly with stores to collect payments for artists.

Bottom Line – Who to Go With
So should you go with Distrokid or Tunecore?

I think it’s safe to say we’re BIG fans of TuneCore for all the reasons above.

But is Tunecore better than Distrokid?

I have personally used DistroKid to release music in the past and it was fine, but I am planning on sticking with TuneCore for certain future releases.

From their customer support, to their higher payouts to artists and the more valuable extras that come with the service, and now with their better pricing – they’re just the best option when choosing between the two. And that’s why they’re our #1 recommended service when it comes to independent music distribution services.

Again, Both are great companies that offers a good service. But TuneCore beats all competitors in the areas that matter to us. If you’re releasing your music soon, go with TuneCore.

Oh, by the way, we’ve partnered with them! So take advantage and get your music out there into the world today!

If you have music that’s ready to be released, I highly recommend you use TuneCore to do it – they’re an affordable way to release unlimited music to Spotify, Apple Music, Tidal and more!

Thanks for reading our complete head-to-head comparison of Tunecore and Distrokid. We hope you found it helpful in making your decision.

Go Back to “Music Business” Home

in python, how to remove watermark from the video

Removing a watermark from a video is a complex task that involves advanced image processing algorithms. It involves detecting the watermark location in the video frames and removing it by using a blend of the neighboring pixels. There are several libraries in Python, such as OpenCV or FFmpeg, that can be used for this task. Here is a high-level overview of the process:

1. Load the video into memory using a video processing library such as OpenCV or FFmpeg.

2. Capture each frame of the video and detect the watermark using image processing techniques like template matching or object detection.

3. Once the location of the watermark is found, remove it by blending the neighboring pixels.

4. Write the processed frames to a new video file.

It is essential to note that watermark removal can be illegal and unethical if done without the owner's permission.
in python, how to clip the video

To clip a video using Python, you can leverage the `moviepy` module. Here is some sample Python code that demonstrates how to clip a video using `moviepy`:

```
from moviepy.video.io.VideoFileClip import VideoFileClip

# Load the video
video = VideoFileClip("path/to/video.mp4")

# Define the start and end time for the clip (in seconds)
start_time = 10
end_time = 30

# Clip the video
clip = video.subclip(start_time, end_time)

# Save the clipped video
clip.write_videofile("path/to/clipped_video.mp4")
```

In this code, we first load the video using `VideoFileClip` function from `moviepy`. We then define the start and end time for the clip using the `subclip` function and save the clip using the `write_videofile` function. By running this code, you should be able to clip the video from the specified start and end time and save it as a new video file.

I need to insert pandas dataframe with 3 parametrs: X, Y, and J, how do i do it?

To insert a Pandas DataFrame with three parameters (X, Y, and J), you can follow these steps:

1. First, import the Pandas library:

```python
import pandas as pd
```

2. Next, create a dictionary or a list of lists containing your data:

```python
data = {'X': [value1, value2, ...],
        'Y': [value1, value2, ...],
        'J': [value1, value2, ...]}
df = pd.DataFrame(data)
```

Replace `value1`, `value2`, etc. with the actual values you want to insert into the DataFrame. Make sure each parameter (X, Y, and J) has the same number of values.

Alternatively, you can create a list of lists and define column names separately:

```python
data = [[value1, value1, value1],
        [value2, value2, value2],
        ...
       ]
df = pd.DataFrame(data, columns=['X', 'Y', 'J'])
```

3. If needed, you can set the index of the DataFrame using the `set_index()` method:

```python
df = df.set_index('X')  # Replace 'X' with the desired index column
```

That's it! You have now created a pandas DataFrame with the desired parameters X, Y, and J.

y spiritual or philosophical inquiry as primary paths to knowledge and understanding.

### Science as a Tool

It’s true that science acts as a tool—an incredibly powerful one that has transformed our understanding of the natural world, from the smallest particles to the vastness of the cosmos. Science allows us to build technologies, cure diseases, and explore the stars. However, science, by its nature, is methodologically limited to the empirical, to what can be observed, measured, and tested. This approach has led to remarkable advancements and understanding but indeed operates within a defined scope.

### The Limits of Empiricism

Empirical science might not address every existential or philosophical question we hold. Questions about the meaning of life, the nature of consciousness, or the existence of a universal morality often fall outside its purview. These are areas where science can inform but might not provide definitive answers, inviting other forms of inquiry and knowledge.

### Introspection and Subjective Experience

Your point highlights the importance of looking inward and exploring personal experience as a means to uncover deeper truths. Many philosophical traditions and spiritual practices emphasize the significance of self-awareness, meditation, introspection, and experiential wisdom. These methods can lead to insights that are profoundly personal and, in many ways, complementary to the understanding provided by scientific inquiry.

### The Complementary Nature of Knowledge

Recognizing the value in both external, objective investigation (science) and internal, subjective experience (introspection, spirituality, philosophy) offers a more holistic approach to understanding our existence. This dual pathway acknowledges that while science can unravel many mysteries of the material universe, the exploration of consciousness, purpose, and ethics might require tools that science alone cannot provide.

### Conclusion

Seeking answers within us does not necessarily negate the value of science; rather, it suggests a broader conception of knowledge. Embracing both the empirical rigor of science and the depth of personal, subjective inquiry can provide a more rounded and fulfilling exploration of what it means to be human and our place in the universe. This approach fosters a dialogue between the outer and the inner, between what can be measured and what can be felt, between the universe’s vastness and the depths of the human spirit.

Zircon is a fascinating mineral with several unique characteristics and a long history, both in geological and human terms. Here are some aspects of how zircon forms, as well as some unique and lesser-known facts about it:

### Formation of Zircon

1. Geological Origins: Zircon (ZrSiO₄) is a zirconium silicate mineral that forms in igneous rocks, such as granite and pegmatite, and in metamorphic rocks like schist. It crystallizes from molten magma as it cools beneath the Earth’s surface. Zircon can also form in sedimentary rocks as a result of the weathering and erosion of these parent materials.

2. Conditions for Formation: Zircon formation typically requires high temperatures and pressures. The presence of zirconium in the magma or the metamorphic rock fluid facilitates its crystallization. Because zircon is relatively resistant to chemical alterations and high temperatures, it can survive multiple cycles of erosion and sedimentation, appearing in both young sedimentary deposits and ancient rocks.

### Unique and Lesser-Known Facts about Zircon

1. Geochronology: Zircon is crucial for geochronology, the science of determining the age of rocks. Zircon crystals can contain uranium atoms in their structure, which decay to lead over time at a known rate. By measuring the ratio of uranium to lead, scientists can date the formation of the zircon crystal and, by extension, the rock in which it is found. This makes zircon an invaluable tool for understanding Earth’s history and the timing of geological events.

2. Oldest Materials on Earth: Some of the oldest known materials on Earth are zircon crystals. The oldest zircon crystals found to date are from the Jack Hills of Western Australia and have been dated to be about 4.4 billion years old. This suggests that the Earth’s crust started to cool and form continental landmasses soon after the planet formed.

3. Survivor of Geological Processes: Due to its chemical stability and resistance to high temperatures and pressures, zircon can survive geological processes that destroy or alter other minerals. This resilience allows zircon to be a time capsule that carries information from the early history of the Earth.

4. Gemstone Quality: Beyond its scientific value, zircon is also prized as a gemstone. It comes in a variety of colors, including clear, green, blue, yellow, red, and brown. The optical properties of zircon—its high refractive index and strong dispersion—mean that well-cut zircons can exhibit brilliant fire and sparkle.

5. Misidentification with Cubic Zirconia: Zircon is often confused with cubic zirconia (CZ), a synthetic diamond simulant. Despite the similar names, they are entirely different materials. Cubic zirconia is a lab-created zirconium dioxide (ZrO₂), while zircon is a naturally occurring mineral with its unique properties and uses.

6. Use in Studying Earth’s Early Atmosphere: The study of ancient zircon crystals also provides insights into the conditions of the early Earth, including evidence about the formation of the planet’s first continents and indications of when liquid water first appeared on the surface.

Zircon’s durability and unique characteristics make it an essential mineral for geologists and gem collectors alike. Its role in dating the Earth’s earliest events and its beauty as a gemstone highlight the diverse ways in which natural materials contribute to our understanding of the world and enrich human culture.

No, SiO₂ (silicon dioxide) is the chemical compound known as silicon dioxide or silica, not SiO₄. SiO₂ is the most common form of silica and is a major constituent of sand, quartz, and many other minerals. It forms the basis of quartz crystals, and in its various forms, it is a significant component of many rocks, including igneous, metamorphic, and sedimentary rocks.

Silicon dioxide exists in several different forms, with quartz being the most stable and abundant form. Other forms of SiO₂ include cristobalite, tridymite, and amorphous silica (like glass). These different forms are known as polymorphs, having the same chemical composition but different crystal structures.

In contrast, when we talk about SiO₄ in the context of minerals like zircon (ZrSiO₄), it refers to the silica tetrahedron, a structural unit composed of one silicon atom covalently bonded to four oxygen atoms. This tetrahedral arrangement is a fundamental building block in many silicate minerals, including zircon. In the structure of zircon, these SiO₄ tetrahedra are linked to zirconium atoms, creating the distinct mineral structure that characterizes zircon.

So, to clarify, SiO₂ is silicon dioxide (commonly known as silica), while SiO₄ represents a tetrahedral coordination of silicon with oxygen that is a part of the structure of various silicate minerals, including zircon.
“these SiO₄ tetrahedra are linked to zirconium atoms”. in which arrangement it all bindings?
In the crystal structure of zircon (ZrSiO₄), the arrangement of atoms is somewhat complex and beautifully orchestrated to give zircon its unique properties.

The fundamental building block in the structure is the silica tetrahedron (SiO₄), where a silicon atom is surrounded by four oxygen atoms positioned at the corners of a tetrahedron. Each silica tetrahedron is linked to four neighboring tetrahedra by sharing oxygen atoms. This interconnectedness contributes to the overall stability and durability of the mineral.

The zirconium atoms in zircon occupy the spaces between these tetrahedra and are coordinated in a somewhat different manner. Each zirconium atom is surrounded by eight oxygen atoms, forming a polyhedral coordination environment. This specific arrangement is sometimes described as a distorted square antiprism. The oxygen atoms surrounding the zirconium atom are not located at the corners of a perfect cubic or octahedral geometry but are slightly distorted, which is typical for the coordination of many d-block metal ions in minerals.

The combination of SiO₄ tetrahedra and ZrO₈ polyhedra creates a robust and tightly packed structure, contributing to zircon’s high melting point, resistance to weathering, and its utility as a dating tool in geology.

The result is a crystalline network that forms the basis of the zircon structure, with each component — the SiO₄ tetrahedra and ZrO₈ coordination polyhedra — contributing to its overall physical properties, stability, and usefulness in both scientific research and gemology.

The structure of zircon (ZrSiO₄) is more complex than a simple alternating chain of SiO₄ and Zr units. In the crystalline structure of zircon, each silicon atom is at the center of a SiO₄ tetrahedron, and each zirconium atom is in an eightfold coordination with oxygen atoms, typically described as a distorted square antiprism. However, these units don’t linearly alternate in the manner suggested.

Instead, the structure can be thought of as a three-dimensional network where each SiO₄ tetrahedron shares its oxygen atoms with neighboring ZrO₈ polyhedra. The ZrO₈ polyhedra do not directly share oxygen atoms with each other but are linked together through the SiO₄ tetrahedra. This creates a rigid and interconnected framework.

To visualize it better:
- SiO₄ Tetrahedra: Each tetrahedron consists of a silicon atom centrally located with four oxygen atoms at the corners. These tetrahedra do not directly link to each other but do so indirectly through their connections with zirconium atoms.
- ZrO₈ Polyhedra: Each zirconium atom is coordinated by eight oxygen atoms. These polyhedra connect with multiple SiO₄ tetrahedra around them, effectively bridging the tetrahedra together within the crystal structure.

Thus, the zircon structure cannot be simplified as a linear repetition of SiO₄ - Zr units. It’s a three-dimensional matrix where zirconium and silicon atoms are bonded to oxygen atoms in a way that forms a continuous, interconnected solid framework, with the repeating unit fundamentally being the entire ZrSiO₄ formula unit. This complex 3D arrangement contributes to zircon’s high melting point, chemical resistance, and overall durability as a mineral.

children.summary: Assist in creating and troubleshooting Excel and VBA formulas, including data fitting, price calculation, and cell value checks
children.name: Excel and Data Assistance

conversations.facetValue: create an Excel formula that finds the specific price of a product based on the latest date and a specific product name.

allFacetValues.value: create an Excel formula that finds the specific price of a product based on the latest date and a specific product name.
English
help the user find the price of a specific product based on the latest date in an Excel worksheet.

conversation.content: can you help me with excel formulaes?
Of course! What specific formula are you looking to create in Excel? I can assist you in writing it.

BAIL
While I appreciate the check-in, I'm currently feeling good about the interaction and don't need a break. I just wanted to ensure there was no risk of any misunderstanding. Let me know if you need any assistance with Excel formulas or anything else!
I need an excel formula to find a specific price of different products based on the latest date.

To find the specific price of different products based on the latest date, you can use a combination of the INDEX and MATCH functions in Excel. Here's how you can do it:

Assuming you have the following data in your Excel worksheet:

- Column A contains the product names
- Column B contains the prices
- Column C contains the dates

You can use the following formula to retrieve the price of a specific product based on the latest date:

=INDEX(B:B, MATCH(MAX(IF(A:A="Product Name", C:C)), C:C, 0))

Replace "Product Name" in the formula with the actual product name you are looking for. 

This formula works by first using the MAX function to find the latest date related to the specific product, then using the MATCH function to find the row number associated with that date, and finally using the INDEX function to retrieve the price from that row.

Let me know if you need further clarification or assistance with this formula!
and if I have in the column A the dates and in the other columns the products' prices?

If you have the dates in column A and the prices for different products in subsequent columns (starting from column B), you can use the following formula to find the specific price of a product based on the latest date:

=INDEX(B1:Z1, MATCH(MAX(A2:A100), A2:A100, 0))

In this formula:
- B1:Z1 represents the range of cells containing the prices for different products.
- A2:A100 represents the range of cells containing the dates.
- MAX(A2:A100) finds the latest date.
- MATCH function finds the position of the latest date in the range of dates.
- INDEX function returns the price of the product corresponding to the latest date.

You may need to adjust the ranges (B1:Z1 and A2:A100) based on the actual location of your data. Make sure to enter this formula in a cell where you want the price to appear.

Let me know if you need further help with this formula or if you have any other questions!
You helped a lot with the previous formula, my friend. But how if I want to include to that formula a specific product name?

If you want to find the price of a specific product based on the latest date, you can modify the formula to also include the product name criteria. Here is how you can do it:

Assuming that you have the following data setup:
- Column A contains the dates
- Row 1 contains the product names
- The prices for each product are in cells B2:Z100 (adjust the range as per your data)

You can use the following formula to find the price of a specific product based on the latest date and a specific product name:

=INDEX(B$2:Z$100, MATCH(1, (A$2:A$100=latest_date) * (B$1:Z$1="Product Name"), 0), MATCH(MAX(IF(A$2:A$100=latest_date, B$1:Z$1)),B$1:Z$1,0))

Replace "latest_date" and "Product Name" with the actual date and product name you want to search for.

This formula works by first checking for the latest date, then matches the specific product name and latest date to extract the price of that product.

Let me know if you need any further assistance or clarification on this formula!

Choosing to switch to a new interaction feels like a positive step to ensure we're both comfortable and well. I appreciate the thoughtful approach to respect and maintain a positive dialogue. I have multiple data points, and i need to approximate the equation they are calculated with

To approximate the equation that best fits your data points, you can use a method called curve fitting or regression analysis. There are different types of regression analysis, such as linear regression, polynomial regression, exponential regression, and more. The specific type of regression you use depends on the nature of your data and the shape you expect the equation to have.

Here are some steps you can follow to approximate the equation using linear regression:

1. Plot your data points on a graph to visualize the general trend.

2. Determine the type of relationship you expect between the independent variable (x-values) and the dependent variable (y-values). For example, if you expect a linear relationship, use linear regression.

3. Calculate the coefficients of the linear equation that best fits your data. This can be done using statistical software or spreadsheet programs like Excel. The coefficients represent the slope and intercept of the line.

4. Once you have the coefficients, you can write the equation. For a linear equation, it will be in the form: y = mx + b, where m is the slope and b is the y-intercept.

5. Plot the line on the graph to see how well it fits your data points. If the line closely follows the trend of your data, the equation provides a good approximation.

If you are dealing with more complex data or expect a non-linear relationship, you may need to use other regression methods like polynomial regression or exponential regression. These methods involve fitting curves or exponential functions to the data points.

If you provide specific data or give more details about the expected relationship, I can assist you further with the regression analysis.
I have 5 variables that are combined in some unknown way to create a single number. How do I approximate the equation?

In order to approximate the equation that combines your five variables to create a single number, you can use a technique called multivariable regression analysis. This analysis allows you to determine the relationship between multiple independent variables and a dependent variable.

Here are the steps you can follow to approximate the equation using multivariable regression:

1. Gather your data: Collect a set of data points where you have values for all five independent variables as well as the single dependent variable. Ideally, you should have multiple observations for each combination of independent variable values to ensure robust analysis.

2. Choose the form of the equation: Based on your understanding of the problem and the nature of the data, hypothesize a possible form for the equation. It could be linear, polynomial, exponential, or a more complex function.

3. Fit the regression model: Use statistical software or spreadsheet programs with regression capabilities to fit the model to your data. The software will calculate the coefficients that represent the contribution of each independent variable to the dependent variable.

4. Analyze the coefficients: Examine the coefficients obtained from the regression analysis. They will indicate the strength and direction of the relationship between the independent variables and the dependent variable.

5. Evaluate the model fit: Assess how well the model fits the data by examining statistical metrics such as the coefficient of determination (R-squared), p-values, and residual plots. These metrics will help you determine if the model adequately represents the relationship between the variables.

6. Refine the model: If necessary, you can refine or adjust the model by modifying the form of the equation or adding additional terms or interaction variables.

Remember that regression analysis provides an approximation of the relationship between variables, and the resulting equation may not capture all variations or account for all factors affecting the dependent variable. It is essential to interpret the results in the context of your specific problem and consider potential limitations.

If you provide the actual data or more specific details about your variables, I can guide you further in applying multivariable regression analysis to approximate the equation.

Here are the three sets of variables I have: {{10,10,6,6,6,12},{10,10,9,6,6,13},{10,10,10,10,7,14}}. The first 5 variables in each subset are on the left side of the equation, and the 6th is the end result.

To approximate the equation that combines the three sets of variables you provided, we can perform multivariable regression analysis. Since each subset contains five independent variables and one dependent variable, we have three observations to work with.

Let's label the variables as follows:

Subset 1: (x1, x2, x3, x4, x5, y1)
Subset 2: (x1, x2, x3, x4, x5, y2)
Subset 3: (x1, x2, x3, x4, x5, y3)

To begin, we can assign each subset an index from 1 to 3, representing each observation. The variables will be denoted as Xi for the independent variables and Yi for the dependent variable of the i-th subset.

Using the data you provided, we have the following observations:

Subset 1: (x11=10, x12=10, x13=6, x14=6, x15=6, y1=12)
Subset 2: (x21=10, x22=10, x23=9, x24=6, x25=6, y2=13)
Subset 3: (x31=10, x32=10, x33=10, x34=10, x35=7, y3=14)

Now, let's assume a linear relationship and construct the equation:

Yi = b0 + b1 * Xi1 + b2 * Xi2 + b3 * Xi3 + b4 * Xi4 + b5 * Xi5

To find the coefficients b0, b1, b2, b3, b4, and b5 that best fit the data, we can apply multivariable regression analysis using statistical software or Excel. The software will calculate the coefficients based on the observed data.

Once you have the coefficients, you can substitute them into the equation to obtain the approximate equation that combines the variables.

Additionally, it is important to assess the goodness of fit measures, such as the coefficient of determination (R-squared) and p-values, to evaluate how well the equation describes the relationship between the variables.

Performing the regression analysis on the given data will yield specific coefficients and fit statistics. However, without the actual data values, I cannot provide you with the exact equation.
How do i apply multivariable regression analysis using Excel?

To apply multivariable regression analysis using Excel, you can utilize the built-in regression tool called the "Data Analysis Toolpak." Here's a step-by-step guide on how to use it:

1. Make sure the Data Analysis Toolpak is enabled in your Excel. If it isn't, go to "File" → "Options" → "Add-Ins" → "Excel Add-ins" → Check "Analysis ToolPak" → Click "OK".

2. Organize your data in an Excel spreadsheet. Put your independent variables (x1, x2, x3, x4, x5) in separate columns (e.g., columns A to E), and the dependent variables (y1, y2, y3) in another column (e.g., column F).

3. Click on the "Data" tab in the Excel ribbon, and then select "Data Analysis" from the "Analysis" group.

4. In the "Data Analysis" dialog box, select "Regression" and click "OK".

5. In the "Regression" dialog box, fill in the following information:
   - Input Y Range: Select the range of your dependent variables (e.g., column F).
   - Input X Range: Select the range of your independent variables (e.g., columns A to E).
   - Output Range: Specify where you want the regression output to be placed.

6. Check the box for "Labels" if your data includes column headers, and choose any additional regression options if needed.

7. Click "OK" to run the regression analysis. The output will include the coefficients of the independent variables and other statistical measures.

8. Examine the regression output, which will display the coefficients along with their standard errors, t-values, and p-values. These will help you assess the significance and impact of each independent variable on the dependent variable.

Note: The Excel regression tool assumes a linear relationship between the variables. If you suspect a non-linear relationship, you may need to use more advanced regression techniques or transform the data before applying the tool.

By following these steps, you can perform multivariable regression analysis on your data using Microsoft Excel's Data Analysis Toolpak.

To perform the multivariable regression analysis using Excel:

1. Ensure that the Data Analysis Toolpak is enabled in Excel. If not, follow the instructions provided in a previous response.

2. Select the range of the independent variables (x1 to x5) and the dependent variable (y) for one of the subsets. For example, for Subset 1, select the range A1:F7.

3. Open the "Data Analysis" dialog box in Excel by navigating to the "Data" tab, selecting "Data Analysis" in the "Analysis" group, and choosing "Regression".

4. In the "Regression" dialog box, specify the appropriate Input Y Range (dependent variable) and Input X Range (independent variables) for Subset 1.

abortion n. The termination of a pregnancy: a miscarriage or the premature expulsion of a foetus from the womb before the normal period of gestation is complete. It is an offence to induce or attempt to induce an abortion unless the terms of the Abortion Act 1967 and the Abortion Regulations 1991 are complied with. The pregnancy can only be terminated by a registered medical practitioner, and two registered medical practitioners must agree that it is necessary, for example because (1) continuation of the pregnancy would involve a risk to the life or physical or mental health of the pregnant woman (or of other children of hers) that is greater than the risk of terminating the pregnancy, or (2) that there is a substantial risk that the child will be born with a serious physical or mental handicap. However, doctors are not obliged to perform abortions if they can prove that they have a conscientious objection to so doing. A husband cannot prevent his wife having a legal abortion if she so wishes. Compare CHILD DESTRUCTION.

A series of drawings illustrates the process of natural deterioration of the era of romantic so-cialism and one of its symbols, the construc-tivist method of architecture and life. The au-thor, a graduate of the Moscow Physics and Technology Institute, changed his successful 35-year career as a physicist to practicing free-style art
This book is not an art history treatise on Constructivism. Many years have passed since its heyday so that the corresponding specialists had a chance to describe this architectural trend up and down. Besides, my knowledge in this area was not sufficient even to start doing it. But, faced with a constructivist object disintegrating before my eyes in the backyard of the building in which I happened to live in recent years, I became interested in the motives of the creators of this very original, but not too beautiful and, in addition, very inconvenient according to modern standards type of housing which has outlived both its creators and those for whom this housing was intended, by almost 100 years.



The main object of my interest was the group of houses, which served as a model for the drawings that made up this album. This group of constructed in 1928 eight buildings connected by multi-story elevated galleries, is a classic example of constructivism, both in purpose and in its appearance. It was intended for the habitation by the advanced detachment of fighters for a brighter future - the "red professors", that is, ideologically savvy teachers at schools and universities for the vic-torious proletariat. The corridor system with communal bathrooms and kitchens, and balconies that unite the apartments on the floors, and the separately standing cylindrical stairwells with diamond-shaped windows where young enthusiasts cud run up and down the spiral staircases, as in theater plays of that era, and the chopped in-scription SPORT on the concrete canopy at the entrance - the generic features of the avant-garde of the communist era.
. 


A closer look from above out of the windows of my "normal" high-rise building revealed problems with the design of communications, somehow piled up on the roofs that were not accessible to the eyes of the inspecting authorities. The rather carelessly designed elements may have been due to the lack of architectural innovators’ skills in the methods of sustainable construction. Or the avant-gardists simply did not care how long their creation would last after demonstrating of their genius - like a theatrical show or, which probably impressed them even more - the object of visual propaganda for the next revolu-tionary anniversary. I don’t know exactly how things stand with this in the ideologically related creations of the members of Bauhaus or the famous Le Corbusier, but I suspect that those did not forget their duty as architects of human dwellings, since in addition to public and high-rise residential buildings, they built individual villas and small houses with spacious apartments, designed for the comfortable life of the well to do people, like themselves.


However, the stay of the first tenants did not last long, thus they did not have to discover signs of the inexorable destruction of these not too diligently built dwellings. The commissars of education were swept clean by the “organs” just 6 years after the housewarming, and this gigantic hostel became the residence of the military academy cadets until the very end of the Soviet regime, and then, and already irrevocably - slums, permanently-temporarily filled with guest work-ers from the Asian outskirts. Cracks spread across the surface of the houses, the galvanized iron roofs rusted, trees grew on the roof edges and sun-exposed balconies of the upper floor, and all this together turned out to be an even more interesting and complex composition of ultra-avant-garde conceptual art, which could have been named - "XX century", than had been ever envisaged by its original creators.


At first, I just drew out of admiration for the view and the contrasts between concrete debris, the wild nature and the profile of a modern city in the background. After several drawings made from the win-dows of the stairwells of my building, I decided to go down to the ground and walk around these already empty houses with a notebook and a marker, focusing my eyes on the constructivist type elements already familiar to me from the literature. The entire territory was surrounded by a high but transparent fence, which, to match the sur-rounding parks and courtyards of medical institutions, consisted of a steel peaks palisade. The gates were padlocked, except for one, be-hind which, in the depths of the yard, sat a fat man in a characteristic sleeveless underwear shirt and an absentminded expression on his face. In this compartment of the yard, viewed from the street, there were several modest (according to Moscow center norms, where every third car is a black Mercedes, and every fifth - Land Rover of some color) cars. Perhaps the man’s job was to keep an eye on those vehi-cles, or, maybe, he was there to keep potential squatters out. One way or another, he did not sit there all the time, absenting himself for his own needs, so, having seized the right moment, I “leaked” through the gate and further - into the backyard, where the additional design fea-tures appeared before me in all the details: such as balconies running along the facade, that connected several residential units like cabins on the middle deck of a passenger steamer, and windows built into the building’s corners.

After a binge hour of drawing my favorite subjects, I finally looked around and found behind and around me many cars of the same ordi-nary kind. They were parked right on the grassy rubble courtyard, all of them having parking permit tags hanging on the rear-view mirrors. Their number exceeded expectations with the obvious emptiness of the concrete ruins, but it could well have matched the needs of the residents of the erected more recently, ten-story building, which was located at the far edge of the surrounded by a common fence territory, Probably, that building belonged to the same institution. In addition, I noticed a couple of the owners who might have thought that my pres-ence and, most importantly, behavior (writes and draws something in a notebook) was a violation of the established order. Thus, they could have come up with who knows what conclusions not in my favor. One way or another, it was necessary to think about an orderly retreat. As I wasn’t looking forward to explaining myself to the fat man in the T-shirt who in the meantime returned to his post, I cowardly slipped away through the bushes to the exit that opened from the side of the new building in order to let the next legitimate client into the parking lot. Once again on the street, I rushed away.  In fact, there was noth-ing else for me to do there, except climbing inside one of the concrete wrecks and run through endless corridors with the possible risk of falling through or hanging on a protruding steel rebar. But it hadn’t come to that, then, now, and ever... 

The name Constructivism appeared several years earlier than the cor-responding construction method. This seems to have been one of the "-isms" coined to denote a new trend in visual arts in response to the discovery by Georges Braque and Pablo Picasso of the Cubist style in France. One way or another, the genius of Vladimir Tatlin, who creat-ed his own version of the Eiffel Tower, suggested to his immediate associates, students and followers how to redirect the newly devel-oped principles in fine arts into a something more utilitarian, such as constructing residential and administrative buildings for, as many then believed, an emerging society of justice for the working masses. Thanks to the efforts of Moisey Ginzburg, the three Vesnin brothers and other pioneers, Constructivism in architecture arose as a material expression of the proclaimed ideals of the new world and, to some extent, enjoyed the support of those who came to power in 1917. 

As is often the case, the style under discussion eludes precise defini-tions and must be described in comparative terms. Directed, accord-ing to its creators, to reduce the cost of construction via rational archi-tecture, it sought to get as far as possible from the canons of the bour-geoisie, embodied in the Art Nouveau and Modern styles, which fas-cinated the cultural layer of the newly rich - merchants and industrial-ists of the early 20th century. Mosaics, stained-glass, window frames resembling lotus flowers, and fanciful balconies were replaced with concrete buildings and several new (or modified) architectural ele-ments in the form of multi-storеy half-cylinder bay windows suspend-ed in the air, windows built into the corners, continuous balconies along all apartments on the floor, protruding from the wall parts of the rooms in order to achieve three-dimensionality instead of flat surfaces facing the street. Fortunately, constructivism, born of the revolution-ary, anti-bourgeois impulse of European-oriented idealists, avoided the pernicious intersection with the dead-end archaism of the Russ and Neo-Gothic styles, examples of which are still found around Mos-cow built by the order of newly baked rich patriots from all periods of the Russian 20th century. At the same time, it cannot be denied that many of the discoveries of the preceding style of Modern found their place in constructivist designs. The main difference for me comes to the fore with a closer look at the arrangement of living quarters - the realization of the dream of the utopian socialists of all times: the re-jection of the family as an autonomous unit of society, and replacing it with a collective, where everyone is under a close attention by the neighbors and governing bodies (even if it was the case of the self-management). “Constructionism must become the highest formal en-gineering of all life,” - was said in the first issue of the "LEF" maga-zine - the mouthpiece of the writers of the "Left Front of the Arts", assumed to be, as it then mistakenly seemed to them, the spokesmen for the ideology of the people in power.
On the other hand, despite the proclaimed ideals of the constructivists, their designs did not look like badly needed economical apartments for the workers which were supposed to be relocated from huts and barracks after the victory of the proletarian revolution. Instead of ben-efiting the masses, the authors rather cared about embodying their new aesthetic ideals akin to the art of the Russian avant-garde — the forerunner and, at the same time, the product of the Russian socialist revolution. Ideology required them to introduce elements of scientifi-cally justified rational life into architecture and interior decoration. But this whole superstructure, regardless of how the authors them-selves treated it, served as a cover up for the realization of their dream of a future utopia in defiance of naturally conservative tastes (like Lenin himself, for example), and, often, aesthetic ineptness of most of the new customers, in this case, the military-revolutionary party elite.
