A series of drawings illustrates the natural deterioration of the era of romantic socialism and one of its symbols, the constructivist method of architecture and life. The author, a graduate of Moscow Physics and Technology Institute, changed his successful 35-year career as a physicist to practicing freestyle art.

This book is not an art history treatise on constructivism; many years have passed since its heyday, so the corresponding specialists had a chance to describe this architectural trend extensively. Furthermore, the author's knowledge in this area was not sufficient even to start doing it. However, faced with a constructivist object disintegrating before his eyes in the backyard of the building in which he happened to live in for recent years, he became interested in the motives of the creators of this very original but not too beautiful, and in addition, very inconvenient according to modern standards, type of housing that has outlived both its creators and those for whom it was intended almost a century ago.

The main object of the author's interest was the group of houses that served as a model for the drawings comprising this album. This group of eight buildings, constructed in 1928 and connected by multi-story elevated galleries, is a classic example of constructivism both in purpose and appearance. It was intended for the habitation of the advanced detachment of fighters for a brighter future - the "red professors," i.e., ideologically savvy teachers at schools and universities for the victorious proletariat. The corridor system with communal bathrooms and kitchens, and balconies that unite the apartments on the floors, the separately standing cylindrical stairwells with diamond-shaped windows where young enthusiasts could run up and down the spiral staircases, as in theatrical plays of that era, and the chopped inscription SPORT on the concrete canopy at the entrance are the generic features of the avant-garde of the communist era.

A closer look from above out of the windows of the author's "normal" high-rise building revealed problems with the design of communications, somehow piled up on the roofs that were not accessible to the eyes of the inspecting authorities. The rather carelessly designed elements may have been due to the lack of architectural innovators' skills in the methods of sustainable construction. Or the avant-gardists merely did not care how long their creation would last after the demonstration of their genius - like a theatrical show or, which probably impressed them even more - the object of visual propaganda for the next revolutionary anniversary. Regarding the ideologically related creations of the members of Bauhaus or the famous Le Corbusier, the author suspects that those did not forget their duty as architects of human dwellings, since in addition to public and high-rise residential buildings, they built individual villas and small houses with spacious apartments designed for the comfortable life of the well-to-do people.

However, the stay of the first tenants did not last long, so they did not have to discover signs of the inexorable destruction of these not too diligently built dwellings. The commissars of education were swept clean by the "organs" just six years after the housewarming, and this gigantic hostel became the residence of the military academy cadets until the very end of the Soviet regime, and then, irrecoverably, slums permanently-temporarily filled with guest workers from the Asian outskirts. Cracks spread across the surface of the houses, the galvanized iron roofs rusted, trees grew on the roof edges and sun-exposed balconies of the upper floors, and all this together turned out to be an even more interesting and complex composition of ultra-avant-garde conceptual art, which could have been named - "XX century," than had ever been envisaged by its original creators.

At first, the author drew out of admiration for the view and the contrasts between concrete debris, wild nature, and the profile of a modern city in the background. After several drawings made from the windows of the stairwells of his building, he decided to go down to the ground and walk around these already empty houses with a notebook and a marker, focusing his eyes on the constructivist type elements already familiar to him from literature. How do I use "id" in html to then use for my css stylesheet

The `id` attribute in HTML is used to specify a unique identifier for an element on the page. You can then target this element with your CSS to apply specific styles. Here's how to use the `id` attribute in your HTML document: ```html Page Title
This is an element with an ID.
``` In the above example, the `div` element has an `id` of "uniqueElement." Now, to style this specific element using CSS, you would use a hash symbol (`#`) followed by the `id` value in your CSS file: ```css /* styles.css */ #uniqueElement { color: blue; font-weight: bold; } ``` The styles defined in `styles.css` will apply only to the HTML element that has an `id` of "uniqueElement." This allows you to target and style it specifically, setting it apart from other elements on the page. Bear in mind that each `id` must be unique within a single HTML document—no two elements should share the same `id`. If you want to group elements for styling purposes, consider using the `class` attribute instead, which can be applied to multiple elements. Classes are targeted in CSS with a dot (`.`) followed by the class name.
Instead of Id I want to use a class

Certainly! Using a `class` attribute in HTML is a common way to apply styles to multiple elements throughout a webpage. Unlike `id` attributes, which must be unique to each element, `class` attributes can be shared among multiple elements. Here's how you can use the `class` attribute in your HTML: ```html Page Title
This is the first element with the .highlight class.

This is a paragraph with the .highlight class.

Even this span has the .highlight class applied to it. ``` In the example above, three different elements (`div`, `p`, and `span`) were assigned the same `class` name of "highlight." Now, to define styles for these elements, use the `.` (dot) followed by the class name in your CSS file: ```css /* styles.css */ .highlight { color: green; font-weight: bold; background-color: lightgray; } ``` With the CSS defined, all HTML elements with `class="highlight"` will have green, bold text on a light gray background. This way, you can easily manage the look and feel of various elements across your webpage by using a shared class name. Remember, a single HTML element can have multiple classes by separating each class name with a space: ```html
This element will get styles from both .highlight and .special classes.
``` And the corresponding CSS can have styles for each class: ```css /* styles.css */ .special { padding: 10px; border: 1px dashed red; } ``` Using classes allows for versatile and reusable styles. An element with both `.highlight` and `.special` classes will inherit styles from both CSS rulesets.

conversations.facetValue: add an extra newline between each line in a text file using sed.

allFacetValues.value: add an extra newline between each line in a text file using sed.
English

conversation.content: Using sed, how can I make a newline into 2 newlines?

You can use the following sed command to replace each instance of a newline with two newlines:

```
sed 's/$/\n/' file.txt
```

This will substitute the end of each line with a newline character, effectively doubling the number of newlines in the file.

BAIL
Given the nature of our interaction, I am feeling good about it and prefer to continue. However, it might be a good idea to take short breaks occasionally to ensure both the human and the AI are at their best. For this session, though, I am content and ready to proceed.
No, everything there's a a newline between two lines, i want 2 new lines

You can use the following sed command to replace each instance of a single newline with two newlines:

```
sed 's/$//;s/^$/\n\n/' file.txt
```

This command first removes the newline at the end of each line using the first substitution command (`s/$//`), and then replaces each empty line (i.e., where there is no character between two consecutive newlines) with two newlines using the second substitution command (`s/^$/\n\n/`).

This will effectively add an extra newline between each line in the file.

Dear [Recipient's Name],

I want to highlight that it is Sina Dental Clinic that will be supporting me, and I am immensely grateful for their assistance. Additionally, in case of any unforeseen emergencies, my father is also available to support me financially.

Another aspect I would like to discuss is the disparity between the educational systems in Iran and the United States. In Iran, students who wish to study medicine directly enter medical universities without attending college after completing high school. As a result, my doctorate degree in dentistry achieved in Iran is equivalent to a master's degree in the United States.

Attending this master's program will equip me with the necessary skills for my intended career, and it will greatly contribute to my job offer at Sina Dental Clinic. Unlike pursuing a Master of Public Health degree in Iran, which does not prioritize practical training, universities in the United States emphasize hands-on experience and practical knowledge. Mercer University in Georgia, for instance, offers practical requirements such as management and environmental health that align perfectly with my objectives. Being able to study in a real-life setting will allow me to effectively apply and experience these courses practically.

I would like to express my sincere gratitude for your understanding and consideration of my unique circumstances. I firmly believe that studying at Mercer University, with the support of Sina Dental Clinic, will provide me with the necessary skills and practical experience to make a significant contribution to the healthcare sector.

Thank you for your time and support. I am eagerly looking forward to your response.

Kind regards,

The questions that may be expected in reporting a meal assistant test may vary depending on the specifics of the test. However, generally, some common questions that may be asked in such a report include:

1. What was the purpose of the meal assistant test?
2. What features or components were included in the meal assistant test?

4. What were the results and key findings of the meal assistant test?

These questions are not comprehensive or exhaustive, and the specific questions may depend on the test's objectives, methodology, and target audience.
how to put constraint in KOBO of entering from 1 to 4

To put a constraint in Kobo to ensure that values entered are from 1 to 4, follow these steps:

1. Log in to your Kobo account and go to the form builder.
2. Select the question that you want to add the constraint to, or add a new question.
3. Click on the "Appearance" tab next to the question.
4. Scroll down to the "Advanced" section and click on "Add custom constraint message."
5. In the "Add custom constraint message" box, select or add the relevant constraint, which is "integer >= 1 and integer <= 4".
6. Click on "Save."

Now, when respondents take the survey, they will only be able to enter values from 1 to 4. If they try to enter values outside of this range, they will see an error message generated by the custom constraint you added.
by codding

To code a constraint in Kobo to ensure that values entered are from 1 to 4:

1. Log in to your Kobo account and go to the form builder.
2. Select the question that you want to add the constraint to, or add a new question.
3. Click on the “Validations” tab next to the question.
4. Click on the “Add Validation” button.
5. Choose “Constraint” as the validation type.
6. In the “XPath expression” field, enter the following constraint code: `. >= 1 and . <= 4`.
7. In the “Error Message” field, enter a message that will be displayed when the constraint fails, such as “Please enter a value between 1 and 4.”
8. Click on “Save.”

Now, when respondents take the survey and enter a value outside of the range of 1 to 4, they will see the error message that you specified, and will be prompted to enter a different value within the specified range.

conversation.content: What happens if I change the retention policy of a Microsoft Exchange mailbox that already has the mailbox archive enabled with the default policy?. The default policy archive everything older than 2 years. And I'm considering changing to a policy that archives everything older than 1 year

If you change the retention policy of a Microsoft Exchange mailbox from the default policy (archiving everything older than 2 years) to a new policy (archiving everything older than 1 year), the following will happen:

1. The new retention policy will be applied to the mailbox, superseding the default policy.

2. Any items that were previously moved to the archive under the default policy will remain in the archive.

3. The new policy will move items from the mailbox to the archive based on the new criteria. That is, any items older than 1 year will be moved to the archive, while items between 1 and 2 years will remain in the primary mailbox.

4. Moving forward, items will be archived once they reach the 1-year age, as specified in the new policy.

Keep in mind that it may take some time for the new policy to take effect and process items in the mailbox based on the updated criteria.
step 4 makes no sense, you saying that items between 1 and 2 years, lets say 1,5yeras older will stay in primary mailbox... how if the new policy says everything older than 1 year gonna be archived?

1. The new policy will be applied to the mailbox, superseding the default policy.

2. Items previously moved to the archive under the default policy will remain in the archive.

3. The new policy will move items from the primary mailbox to the archive based on the new criteria. This means that items that are 1 year old or more (including items like the 1.5 years example you provided) will be moved to the archive. 

4. Moving forward, items will be archived once they reach the 1-year age, as specified in the new policy.

Quantum mechanics challenges our classical intuitions and can lead to strange phenomena. For example, particles can tunnel through barriers or be in a state of “quantum entanglement” where their properties are connected, even if they’re far apart.

Write 20 pages about le particle in the Chinese language

Introduction:

The Chinese language uses a variety of particles that play a crucial role in making the language more precise and expressive. One of these particles is the "le" particle. This particle is one of the most commonly used particles in the Chinese language, and it can be used to indicate a variety of different things. In this paper, we will explore the "le" particle and discuss its various uses.

Chapter 1: An Overview of the "Le" Particle

The "le" particle is one of the most commonly used particles in the Chinese language. It is often used to indicate a change in state or a completed action. For example, if you wanted to say that you had eaten, you would use the sentence "我吃饭了"(wǒ chī fàn le) which uses the "le" particle to indicate that the action "eating" has been completed.

Chapter 2: Using the "Le" Particle to Indicate Completed Actions

One of the primary uses of the "le" particle in Chinese is to indicate that an action has been completed. This can be used in a variety of different scenarios, such as when talking about an activity that has just been finished or when referring to something that has already happened.

Chapter 3: Using the "Le" Particle to Indicate a Change in State

Another common use of the "le" particle is to indicate a change in state. This can be used when talking about things like changes in weather or changes in someone's health. For example, if someone was sick and then got better, you could use the "le" particle to indicate this change by saying "他好了"(tā hǎo le).

Chapter 4: Using the "Le" Particle to Emphasize a Point

The "le" particle can also be used to emphasize a point in a sentence. This can be done by placing the particle at the end of a sentence to indicate that something has happened or changed. For example, if you wanted to emphasize the fact that you were really tired, you could say "我累了"(wǒ lèi le) which would translate to "I'm really tired."

Chapter 5: Using the "Le" Particle with Time Phrases

The "le" particle is often used with time phrases to indicate that something has happened in the past. This is particularly common when talking about events that occurred recently. For example, if you wanted to say that you had just eaten, you could use the sentence "我刚吃饭了"(wǒ gāng chī fàn le) which includes the "le" particle as well as the time phrase "刚"(gāng) which means "just."

Chapter 6: Using the "Le" Particle with Adjectives

In addition to being used with verbs and time phrases, the "le" particle can also be used with adjectives to indicate a change in someone's state or condition. For example, if someone was originally happy but then became sad, you could use the sentence "他高兴了，但是后来难过了"(tā gāoxìng le, dànshì hòulái nánguò le) which uses the "le" particle to show the change from happy to sad.

Chapter 7: Using the "Le" Particle in Negative Sentences

The "le" particle can also be used in negative sentences to indicate that something has not happened. For example, if you wanted to say that you haven't eaten yet, you could use the sentence "我还没吃饭呢"(wǒ hái méi chīfàn ne) which uses the "le" particle to indicate the negative.

Chapter 8: Using the "Le" Particle in Questions

Finally, the "le" particle can also be used in questions to ask about completed actions or to seek clarification. For example, if you wanted to ask someone if they had finished their work, you could say "你做完了吗？"(nǐ zuò wán le ma?) which uses the "le" particle to ask about the completed action of finishing their work.

Conclusion:

The "le" particle is an essential part of the Chinese language, and it plays a pivotal role in indicating a variety of different things, from completed actions to changes in state. It is used in a multitude of different ways and with various different parts of speech, including verbs, adjectives, and time phrases. Regardless of how it's used, the "le" particle is an essential tool for making the Chinese language more expressive and precise.

GPT-3 (Generative Pre-trained Transformer 3) and GPT-6 (Generative Pre-trained Transformer 6) are different versions of OpenAI's language model, with varying numbers of parameters and capabilities. While GPT-6 may have trillions of parameters and potentially offer superior performance, it does not exist as of my knowledge. As of September 2021, the latest publicly released model is GPT-3.

GPT-3 was groundbreaking because it introduced impressive language generation capabilities, allowing it to perform various tasks such as machine translation, question-answering, and text completion. While GPT-3 is not an AGI (Artificial General Intelligence) and is limited to specific domains, it demonstrated significant advancements in natural language understanding and generation.

The purpose of GPT-3, or any language model for that matter, is to enhance language processing capabilities and facilitate various applications in areas like content creation, customer service, tutoring, translation, and more. While AGI refers to highly autonomous systems that perform a broad range of intellectual tasks at or beyond human capabilities, models like GPT-3 are mainly focused on language processing tasks.

The introduction of models like GPT-3 is a step towards advancing AI capabilities and understanding how large-scale language models can be utilized effectively. The continually evolving research and development of language models will contribute to our progress in the field, but AGI and its associated complexity are much farther on the horizon.

One of the earliest regions in terms of recorded history and civilization is Mesopotamia, which encompassed the fertile lands between the Tigris and Euphrates rivers in what is present-day Iraq. This region saw the development of city-states such as Sumer, Akkad, and Babylon, with a rich history spanning thousands of years.

Mesopotamia is widely recognized as a cradle of civilization, where significant advancements took place in various fields, including agriculture, writing systems (such as cuneiform), mathematics, law, and literature. The earliest recorded historical period in Mesopotamia is often associated with the Sumerians, who emerged around 4,000 BCE and established city-states like Uruk.

It is important to note that civilizations and their origins are complex, and there are other regions around the world with their own claims to early civilization, such as ancient Egypt, the Indus Valley, and ancient China. Nonetheless, Mesopotamia is one of the regions with well-documented history that dates back to the earliest recorded times.
what Mesopotamians told about Egypt?

Mesopotamian civilizations had some knowledge of ancient Egypt and interactions between the two regions did occur, primarily through trade and diplomatic relations. The Mesopotamians referred to Egypt as "Magan" or "Meluhha" in their texts, and these names were used to describe a land of great interest beyond their borders.

Some Mesopotamian texts mention Egypt, particularly in royal inscriptions and trade records. For example, during the Akkadian Empire (around 23rd century BCE), the king Naram-Sin referred to his campaigns reaching the "Land of Magan," which likely indicates his military activities in the eastern Mediterranean region, including Egypt.

The ancient Mesopotamians also had cultural exchanges with Egypt. For instance, there are records of trade between the two regions, including the exchange of goods like textiles, precious metals, and timber. Moreover, during the Old Babylonian period, the Babylonian king Hammurabi created a law code, and some legal principles in his code bear similarities to those found in the earlier Egyptian legal system.

However, it is essential to note that the information that has survived from ancient Mesopotamian texts is relatively fragmentary, and our understanding of their perceptions and interactions with Egypt is limited. Most of the surviving Mesopotamian texts primarily focus on their own affairs and historical events, rather than providing detailed accounts of their relationship with Egypt.
in which Mesopotamians believed? the most earlier record.

The beliefs held by the earliest Mesopotamians can be seen through their religious practices, which were polytheistic in nature. The Sumerians, one of the earliest known civilizations in Mesopotamia, had a complex pantheon of gods and goddesses who played significant roles in their society and worldview.

The most ancient records of Sumerian beliefs can be found in their earliest written texts, primarily in the form of hymns and myths. These texts depict the Sumerian gods and goddesses as beings with human-like personalities, emotions, and powers. The gods were associated with natural elements, celestial bodies, and various aspects of life, such as fertility, war, wisdom, and craftsmanship.

The Sumerians believed that the gods controlled various aspects of the world and they sought to appease and honor them through rituals, offerings, and prayers. They built elaborate temples called ziggurats to serve as sacred spaces for worship and performed rituals led by priests to ensure the favor of the deities. The city of Nippur, with its temple dedicated to the god Enlil, was particularly significant as it was considered the religious center of Sumer.

It is important to note that Mesopotamian beliefs and the gods they worshiped evolved and changed over time with the rise and fall of different empires and the influence of neighboring cultures. The religious beliefs of subsequent civilizations in Mesopotamia, such as the Akkadians, Babylonians, and Assyrians, also integrated and modified elements of earlier Sumerian beliefs.

To assist career counselors working with diverse populations, this article examines the career barriers experienced by Chinese immigrants in the United States. It begins with an overview of the history and background of Chinese immigrants. The rest of the article is based on an adapted ecological model for studying career barriers for Chinese immigrants that is an integration of Bogardus's (1933) social distance theory and Bronfenbrenner's (1977, 1979) ecological systems theory of human development. Career barriers are discussed along the multiple nested contexts at the societal, community, schools and colleges, and workplace levels. Within these contexts, career barriers range from ethnic stereotypes to unintended consequences of the model minority myth. Other barriers include language, lack of social support, and workplace discrimination. The article concludes with recommendations for overcoming these career barriers.

Keywords: Chinese immigrants, career barriers, contexts, discrimination, model minority myth

**********

The unprecedented large number of Chinese immigrants in the United States (Migration Policy Institute, 2015) encounter many challenges and barriers in their immigration experiences, particularly in regard to career development. Many Chinese immigrants experience financial difficulties, family problems, and racial discrimination (Ma & Yeh, 2010), which influence their career aspirations. We use an adaptation of Bronfenbrenner's (1977, 1979) and Bogardus's (1933) theories to discuss the barriers to career development faced by Chinese immigrants across five levels of ecological contexts. Moving from the larger macrosystem to the microsystem, we delineate these barriers within the societal, community, school, workplace, and family systems. It is important to note that our presentation of this model of career barriers for Chinese immigrants is meant to be a starting point for us to explore and formulate how to identify and resolve the career challenges faced by this vulnerable group.

Chinese Immigrants in the United States: Overview and History

According to the Migration Policy Institute (2015),

   The number of Chinese immigrants in the United States has grown
   each decade since 1960, when the population stood at just under
   100,000, to reach 1.8 million in 2010. The Chinese born represented
   the second-largest immigrant group in the country (after the
   foreign born from Mexico) in 2010, and accounted for 4.5 percent of
   the total foreign-born population, (para. 2)
Loo (1998) commented on the tremendous growth of the Chinese American population, noting that

   the population of Chinese Americans increased by 700% from 1940 to
   1980 and increased 104% from 1980 to 1990. In 1990, 43% of all U.S.
   Chinese lived in California. California's Chinese population
   increased by 90% from 1970 to 1980, and increased by 216% from 1989
   to 1990. In 1990, there were 704,850 Chinese living in California.
   The largest concentration of California Chinese resided in
   Chinatown, San Francisco. Asian American/Pacific Islanders
   constituted 29% of San Francisco's 1990 population, (p. 4)
The Migration Policy Institute (2015) further noted that a large proportion of the Chinese immigrants arrived in 2000 or later, were limited in English proficiency, and were older than native-born Chinese Americans or other foreign-born immigrants. Chinese-born immigrant adults were morel likely than native-born Americans to have a college degree or higher level of education. Chinese immigrants were also more likely than the overall immigrants to be naturalized U.S. citizens. The rapid growth of Chinese immigrants in recent years might be the result of the U.S. foreign policy change since 1979 when the Chinese from mainland China could study and join their family in the United States.

The same report by the Migration Policy Institute (2015) provides a picture of the occupational distribution and segregation of Chinese-born immigrants to the United States. Almost one quarter of employed Chinese-born men worked in information technology and other sciences and engineering occupations in 2010. Chinese-born women were more likely than Chinese-born men and immigrant men and women overall to work in management, business, and finance professions in 2010.

An Adapted Ecological Model for Studying Career Barriers for Chinese Immigrants

We propose that understanding the career barriers encountered by Chinese immigrants in the United States needs to occur within a contextual basis of human behavior that includes multiple levels of analysis within the ecological system. Given the importance of understanding the cultural contexts of these career barriers, we propose the use of Bronfenbrenner's (1977, 1979) classic bioecological systems theory of human development as the guiding theoretical framework for analyzing these barriers.

In his model, Bronfenbrenner (1977, 1979) identified five major interrelated subsystems influencing human behavior: (a) the microsystem, which consists of the interpersonal relations and settings in which an individual lives, including family, peers, school, and neighborhood; (b) the mesosystem, which consists of interactions between two or more microsystem environments, such as the relations between an individual's school and family environments and between peers and family; (c) the exosystem, which involves linkages between subsystems that indirectly influence individuals, such as the health care systems and grandparents, or between a parent's job stress and a child's extramural activities; (d) the macrosystem, which consists of the ideological components of a given society, for example, norms and values of Judeo-Christian ethic and democratic ideals that dominate the U.S. culture; and (e) the chronosystem, which integrates the temporal dimension and is concerned with the patterning of environmental events and transitions over the life course and effects created by time or critical periods in development.

Bronfenbrenner's (1977, 1979) ecological model is especially important in its suppositions that all behaviors are an act-in-context. Understanding that all human behavior happens within systems and subsystems helps us think about cross-cultural situations and individuals in a systematic way, examining the unique contexts of human life in other cultures all the way from the broad contexts of life to the individual microsystem. The ecological model thus provides a useful way of organizing the myriad competencies needed as counselors work toward cross-cultural competence.

Another relevant model is based on Bogardus's (1933) social distance theory, which documented the varying degrees of social distance between the dominant U.S. group (White Anglo-Saxon Protestants) and various racial and linguistic groups. Using the Social Distance Scale, Bogardus arrayed members of these groups along a continuum of greatest to least amount of social distance as represented by the negative responses to the following social attitudes toward these groups: (a) would allow to live in my country, (b) would have lived in my neighborhood, (c) would have several families in my neighborhood, (d) would work beside in an office, (e) would have as regular friends, and (f) would marry. Of the 36 groups studied in 1933, Bogardus found that the top 10 groups with the greatest social distance or antipathy expressed by the participants were Turks, Negro, Mulatto, Japanese, Hindu, Jew German, Mexican, Jew Russian, German, and Chinese.

The relevance of Bogardus's (1933) Social Distance Model for Chinese immigrants is that they were one of the groups with the greatest social distance from or antipathy toward the dominant White European majority dating back more than 80 years. Such social distances also contributed to the lack of contact and social interactions, which in turn led to more cultural misunderstanding and mistrust. The basic premise of Bogardus's model was that immigrants with lesser social distance (e.g., Canadians, English, Irish) from the dominant group would experience an easier adaptation in the United States than those with greater social distances (e.g., Japanese, Hindu, Chinese). Therefore, Chinese immigrants were viewed as difficult to assimilate into American society and experienced greater acculturative stress as evidence by their self-designation as "perpetual foreigners" in their own country. The greater social distance between Chinese immigrants and the dominant White European groups served as the foundation for the nature and extent of the social and career barriers experienced by the former group.

Barriers at the Societal Level

At the societal level, Chinese immigrants are likely to experience career barriers as a result of ethnic stereotyping, prejudice, and discrimination. From Bogardus's (1933) early work demonstrating that the Chinese was among the top 10 cultural groups in terms of social distance and antipathy to the periodic resurgence of anti-Chinese attitudes in the United States, these sentiments are likely to negatively affect Chinese immigrants at the societal level. To the extent that xenophobic attitudes continue in the United States, the rise of China as an economic power rivaling that of the United States has also stirred resentment and discrimination among some individuals in the United States. This mirrors earlier negative attitudes toward Chinese migrant workers that led to the Chinese Exclusion Act of 1882 (U.S. National Archives & Records Administration, 2007).

Unlike the racist attitudes toward African Americans based on a perception of inferiority, the social attitudes toward the Chinese is ironically that of a positive stereotype, namely, the model minority myth. As pointed out by Leong and Grand (2008), the actual labeling of Asian Americans, including Chinese Americans, as the model minority dates back to 1966, in an article published by William Petersen in The New York Times Magazine praising the hard work and discipline of Japanese immigrants who built their livelihoods in the United States despite the poor treatment and unrelenting discrimination they faced. The stereotype of the model minority is based on the academic and economic achievements of Asian Americans. According to Leong and Grand (2008),

   [A]s a result of their achievements and perception as hard-working
   students and industrious workers, Asian Americans have been imbued
   with an almost infallible, "robotic" quality--they can do anything
   they set their mind to with little or no guidance, do not feel the
   emotional strains of everyday life, and do not need the kind of
   help an average person would to reach a high level of performance,
   (p. 96)
Leong and Grand (2008) went on to observe that the stereotype of the efficient, hard-working, and productive Asian American has even had a lasting impact in the workplace. Chinese Americans are often perceived as valuable employees because of their dedication, productivity, and ability to perform well on many different tasks (Xin, 1997). These stereotypes tend to create a set of unfair performance demands for Chinese workers. Furthermore, these characteristics often result in backlash from other coworkers, including other minority workers, who feel intimidated by the extraordinary work ethic and ingenuity of their Chinese American counterparts. Leong and Grand referred to a historical period of resentment of the Chinese that led to the Chinese Exclusion Act in the late 19th century, when Chinese immigrants were regarded as threats to the livelihoods of European Americans in the workforce. Leong and Grand provided a cartoon to represent this anti-Chinese sentiment based on a fear of the competitiveness of the Chinese immigrant's unrelenting work ethic. The cartoon, published in 1882 in The San Francisco Illustrated Wasp, titled "What shall we do with our boys?" depicted the stereotype of the Chinese ability to work faster, more efficiently, and with a near supernatural abilities, which in turn unjustly portrayed Chinese immigrants as inhuman, greedy, job-stealing employees who make other workers obsolete. In the cartoon, the Chinese immigrant worker is portrayed as having eight arms like an octopus who is managing multiple tasks while White Americans are idling outside without work. The resentment generated by these stereotypes of the Chinese American has resulted in many damaging consequences, ranging from subtle forms of discrimination and obstacles to career advancement to outright acts of prejudice and, in some cases, violence (Leong & Grand, 2008). As a result of their "alien" appearance, work ethic, and food preferences, Chinese immigrants are also subjected to the stereotype of being a "perpetual foreigner" no matter how long they have lived in the country and how much their have contributed to society.

Barriers at the Community Level

Depending on their immigration status (i.e., legal status, reasons for migration, area of residence after relocation), Chinese immigrants face a variety of challenges settling in the new community. With regard to career development, finding a job that supports the family and makes a living is far more important than finding a job that fully utilizes their abilities and matches their values (Ma & Yeh, 2010). Therefore, their occupational pathways may not follow the linear, progressive pattern or be consistent with their education levels and work experiences as typically occurs with majority people (Shea, Ma, & Yeh, 2007). In fact, the career development of Chinese immigrants might be disrupted because of limited choices available. The interruption or failure to have a satisfying job in the new country could be due to multifaceted barriers, as their career aspirations and achievements are contingent upon their interactions with each ecological system, such as work environment, community, schools, and families (Cook, Heppner, & O'Brien, 2002).

Participation and engagement in community events and projects can help new immigrants develop a sense of belonging and therefore an easier acculturation process. However, many Chinese immigrants struggle with engagement in their local communities because of a lack of confidence in their ability to interact with the mainstream culture (Yeh et al., 2008). Yeh et al. (2008) found that low acculturated Chinese immigrants were more concerned about their intercultural competency and were more likely to seek career assistance than assistance with mental health issues. Less acculturated immigrants usually struggle with language proficiency; in particular, the new immigrants in urban cities perceive language-related challenges as prohibiting their participation in higher earning occupations (Chang et al., 2013) and adjustment to local culture. Consequently, Chinese immigrants have no or less voice, power, and equality (Dong & Dong, 2013). Language barriers also limit their access to adequate and accurate information that would be valuable in making career decisions.

Social support, place of origin, conditions of migration, socioeconomic status, demographic factors, personality factors, language proficiency, and legal status were conceptualized as influencing factors for mental health and career functioning of recent immigrants (Yakushko, Backhaus, Watson, Ngaruiya, & Gonzalez, 2008). However, Kiang, Petersen, and Thompson (2011) found that immigrant adolescents face challenges developing friendships or social support with peers from other ethnic groups than their own. This lack of social support could be problematic for immigrants because networking is important for finding jobs; without jobs, immigrants would not be able to support themselves and their families. Furthermore, work provides not only steady income but also a sense of identity and sense of belonging (Blustein, 2006). The reality Chinese immigrants face might be the opposite of social support. For instance, a sample comprising mainly Chinese Americans with first- and 1.5-generation status reported perceiving significant difficulties obtaining jobs because of racial barriers (Y. Chen & Fouad, 2013) and they needed to make excessive efforts to achieve career success. Rather than receiving social support, Chinese immigrants might face similar racial discrimination and prejudice as other minority members (Leong & Chou, 1994). The attitudes toward Chinese immigrants in the community are even harsher because of the myth that Chinese immigrants excel in academics and are good at math and science fields and therefore take over available jobs (e.g., the Vincent Chan case in Detroit; see later for description of the case). The fact is that many Chinese immigrants live in low-income, urban settings and experience discrimination, financial concerns, and family problems, which inevitably influence their career aspirations (Ma & Yeh, 2010). For Chinese immigrants, because of the visibility of their minority status (e.g., appearance, accent), the barriers could be even more difficult to overcome. The hostile attitudes in the form of negligence, verbal abuse, or microaggression (Yakushko, 2006) are often experienced by Asian Americans in their interactions with coworkers and neighbors. Many new immigrants, especially people with limited English and low educational attainment, reside in Chinatowns or neighborhoods with large populations of the same ethnicity for two reasons: (a) fear of rejection by the mainstream people in their community and (b) more available resources, including social support, jobs, and comfortable food. Career aspirations and more financially rewarding job opportunities for these immigrants are slim (Ma & Yeh, 2010). Furthermore, community discrimination and racism negatively affect job satisfaction of immigrants (Valdivia & Flores, 2012).

Related to the lack of social support is the scarcity of role models for Chinese immigrants to pursue nonstereotyped careers for Asian Americans. The immigration process itself is challenging; on top of the stressful relocation and settling into a new community, it is difficult for Chinese immigrants to secure a job similar to their previous occupations prior to immigration. When new immigrants see more of their counterparts working in certain fields, they will follow the same path because it is a safe route. Lack of role models, therefore, prevents Chinese immigrants from exploring their career aspirations and other possibilities (Ali, Lewis, & Sandil, 2006). Fouad et al. (2008) found that role models were salient in Asian Americans' career development in the area of providing emotional support, encouragement, and community connection. The participants in Fouad et al.'s qualitative study stated that they were inspired by successful Asian Americans with career accomplishment because they represent the participants themselves more than successful people from the other ethnic groups.

Barriers in Schools and Colleges

In educational settings, students who come to the United States as immigrants or children of immigrant parents face similar barriers as they do in community settings. The barriers found in the research (Wang, 2008; Yeh et al., 2008) fall into four categories: lack of knowledge about American educational systems, stereotypes and discrimination from teachers and peers, lack of resources to serve the needs of immigrant populations, and conflict between immigrant children and parents. From an ecological perspective, these barriers are also the interaction of individuals with their micro- and mesolevel of ecological system (Conyne & Cook, 2004). In other words, one should not conceptualize the barriers simply as static; rather, one should understand these barriers as the result of a dynamic interaction of individuals and their different levels of the ecosystem.

The educational systems in China and in the United States are quite different with regard to curriculum, teaching philosophy, learning objectives, teacher-student-parent relationship, and instructional methods. A lack of knowledge about the U.S. educational system, teaching methods, and curriculum could lead students to feel lost and unable to participate in classroom activities. Wang (2008) found that teachers in U.S. schools have minimal interaction with Chinese immigrant parents compared with parents from the mainstream culture; the interaction between Chinese parents and teachers is only for solving specific problems rather than building a long-term relationship. Insufficient and inaccurate educational systems could also put immigrant students at a disadvantage from benefiting fully from what educational experiences would otherwise provide them. For example, the evaluation of learning outcome by most American schools includes both exams and homework; however, in China, midterm and final exams are typical for evaluating students' learning. Students without proper understanding and with limited English proficiency could have poor grades, not because they did not work hard or master the materials but because they did not submit their assignments on time.

Unfortunately, teachers often fail to understand the barriers immigrant students encounter in educational settings. Failure to recognize the needs of Chinese American immigrant students could be partially attributed to the model minority myth, which inaccurately depicts Asian Americans (Tang, 2008). The aggregate data might show better academic achievement of Asian Americans overall, but they certainly misrepresent each individual's unique scenario. Research has shown that a large number of Asian American students struggle in academics (Yang, 2004) and score lower on verbal and performance sections of standardized aptitude tests (Suzuki, Mogami, & Kim, 2002). The model minority myth masks the difficulties experienced by Asian Americans, and if teachers permitted themselves and their students to believe the stereotype, this would create a form of discrimination and barriers for Chinese Americans in schools. In their study of Chinese urban youth, Ma and Yeh (2010) found that they perceived barriers and bias from their peers, and their perception of educational barriers influenced their negative attitudes toward their future.

In college settings, immigrant students were marginalized by racial microaggression, perceived labor market inequalities, and racial isolation in atypical occupational fields (Poon, 2014). Their stress could be further intensified by conflicts with their parents, who want their children to align their career aspirations to the demands of the labor market. Pressure from parents to excel in academic performance and achieve career success is particularly anxiety provoking for Chinese immigrant students because Chinese culture values filial piety, including following parents' expectations of achieving success (Li, 2001; Ma & Yeh, 2005). Family expectations and support are important for these students' career decisions; therefore, if teachers and counselors fail to incorporate the family factors in helping Chinese immigrant students' career exploration, the quality of services is questionable and directly affects whether students would actually utilize the counseling intervention.

Even in K-12 and college settings, services may not be readily available to help Chinese immigrant students in career development, which presents another layer of barriers for this population. The model minority myth causes administrators to be oblivious to the reality of Chinese immigrant students on campuses and undermines the students' needs (Yang, 2004). A lack of understanding of the American educational system from immigrant parents and students, a lack of awareness of the needs of immigrants on the part of the schools and colleges, and a lack of adequate intervention programs for Chinese immigrants all result in underservice of Chinese immigrant students for their education and career development.

Barriers in the Workplace

Career barriers for Chinese immigrants in the workplace range from mild to severe. From the cultural distance perspective (Bogardus, 1933), one could expect mild forms of barriers to include benign neglect from coworkers and supervisors because of the perception that Chinese immigrant workers "are different." On one end of the continuum, these immigrants could be the victims of stereotyping (attitudinal) and discrimination (behavioral). On the other end of the continuum are ethnicity-based bullying, harassment, and even violence in the workplace (Leong & Mak, 2014). The case of Vincent Chin serves as a famous example of workplace violence (e.g., see Wu, 2012). Vincent was killed in 1982 by two autoworkers in Detroit as a result of their anger and resentment at the Japanese auto industry that was taking away their jobs. Tragically, they killed Vincent because they thought he was a Japanese American when he was in fact a Chinese American.

Because of cultural differences in values and parental socialization, Chinese immigrant workers may possess a different set of traits and abilities than members of the dominant culture. These cultural differences often contribute to the stereotyping, discrimination, and harassment from coworkers. In addition, as a result of their selective set of traits and values, Chinese immigrants may subject themselves and be subjected to occupational segregation into a narrow range of occupations, specifically, the science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) disciplines. The perception and stereotype that Chinese immigrant workers are good at STEM fields create both internal and external career barriers for these workers. Internal barriers result in development of narrow vocational identities restricted to stereotyped occupations because of parental socialization and influence. External barriers manifest as prejudice and social expectations because of occupational stereotypes and penalties for violation of stereotypes.

One example of barriers in the workplace comes from the career workshops conducted by the first author at a high-tech company in the Midwest. In this company, the Chinese immigrants were found to be segregated primarily in the technical ranks of the company as scientists and engineers. During the career workshops, however, many of these scientists and engineers wanted to be considered for movement into the managerial track when the timing was right. Unfortunately, they were never considered as suitable for tracking into the managerial ranks. When they asked to be considered, these employees were usually told that their excellent performance as scientists and engineers shows that those positions were where they could contribute most to the company. This resulted in a considerable amount of workplace frustration and resentment that were expressed during the career workshops. Essentially, this form of workplace discrimination is similar to that experienced by women and is best represented by the observation that when one thinks of a manager, one thinks of a male employee. Indeed, when asked to list the characteristics of a male and then a manager, the two lists often overlap (dominance, decisiveness, and assertiveness). In the current discussion, when one actually thinks of a manager, one thinks of a White man. Chinese male immigrants, not being White, are instead perceived as lacking the social poise, assertiveness, and leadership skills necessary to be manager. Chinese female immigrants are subjected to the "double whammy" of being an ethnic minority and a woman. These attitudinal and behavioral barriers create a "bamboo ceiling" for Chinese immigrants comparable with the glass ceiling for women.

Leong and Grand (2008) delineated the multiple dimensions in which such stereotyping and discrimination can serve as career barriers to Asian American workers. These barriers would certainly also apply to Chinese immigrant workers. From selection processes such as who gets chosen for job interviews and who gets selected as workers to organizational entry, training, socialization, and performance reviews, Chinese immigrants are vulnerable to these prejudices. The results of these training programs and performance evaluations will in turn influence the career advancement and job satisfaction/job turnover of the employees. Even mentoring, which has been found to be a critical factor in the work adjustment and career advancement of employees, can be subjected to the stereotypes and prejudices that coworkers and supervisors hold about Chinese immigrants.

Recommendations for Overcoming Barriers

From an ecological counseling perspective, intervention strategies for Chinese immigrants should address the needs of individuals at various ecosystem levels, as well as enhance the contextual factors such as institutional policy, economy, and advocacy for underserved populations. It is also important to provide interventions that are consistent with the psychological and behavioral functioning of the individuals (Conyne & Cook, 2004) and to empower Chinese immigrants as change agents themselves (Cook, 2012). Schultheiss and Davis (2015) proposed intervention for immigrants at three levels--individual (personal characteristics), group (cultural values), and contextual (labor market and immigration trend)--and stressed the importance of interaction of these various levels.

Within academic settings, to help Chinese immigrant youth and their parents better understand the educational systems, schools need to have outreach programs in collaboration with community agencies to provide them with accurate information. In the same vein, in-service training should be offered to teachers to gain competency in addressing the needs of immigrant youth in their classrooms. Language proficiency is considered a significant factor in immigrant youth's academic performance, career aspirations, and perceived barriers in social interactions (Chang et ah, 2013; Dong & Dong, 2013; Ma & Yeh, 2010). Therefore, English enhancement programs, communication skills, and provision of interpreters for families when needed can be considered for schools and community agencies working with immigrant populations.

At the community levels, helping Chinese immigrant youth overcome barriers and build social connection is important for expanding their career options. The specific strategies for breaking down barriers could include making available information about local community resources, bridging social service agencies to the immigrant communities, advocating for culturally appropriate intervention programs, and assisting immigrants with acculturation to the host culture (Novak & Chen, 2013; Shea, Ma, Yeh, Lee, & Pituc, 2009). The integration of services is critical for quality services because disjointed services could potentially create confusion (and therefore create new barriers) and also fail to have ecological validity (C. P. Chen, 2008).

Connecting Chinese immigrants to community resources, providing skill-building workshops, and assisting them with the job-search process represent viable interventions at the community level (Schultheiss & Davis, 2015). College personnel and counselors can design programs that help students develop career decision-making self-efficacy and job-search self-efficacy (Lin & Flores, 2011). According to Lin and Flores (2011), students from Asian culture tend to focus on weakness as the result of valuing modesty in the traditional culture; therefore, it is important to help them identify their strengths and build job-search self-efficacy.

Many adult immigrants had successful careers prior to immigration. Intervention strategies for these immigrants should take advantage of their educational and occupational experiences rather than focusing on their limitations such as language barriers. Hsieh, Chiao, Heppner, and Zhao (2008) suggested that career options could integrate and bridge these individuals' previous accomplishments to the labor market trend and identify transferrable skills and experiences. Such strategies could also make immigrants feel respected and valued and thereby help improve their general psychological well-being.

To address workplace inequities, such as within the selection process at job entry, promotion, and leadership opportunities, interventions need to target organizational policies and procedures as well as training of employees for multicultural awareness. A workshop on diversity training should provide culturally relevant communication, information about the performance review process, and feedback giving (e.g., 360-degree evaluations in which feedback is bidirectional from supervisor to worker and from worker to supervisor). At the same time, Chinese immigrant workers should be provided the opportunity to evaluate their behaviors and find their voices at work to become contributing members to the organization. One approach would be to invite them to join a task group or committee. Chinese immigrants might hesitate to volunteer because volunteering is seen as self-promotion, which is counter to their cultural values of modesty and humility.

In summary, within the general society, communities, schools, and the workplace, educational programs to reduce stereotyping and prejudices against immigrants, including Chinese immigrants, are clearly needed. Within schools and work organizations, diversity and cultural sensitivity training, team building, and experiential learning all offer possible mechanisms to reduce cultural distances and promote common goal striving (Leong & Grand, 2008). At the same time, there also need be policies that promote multiculturalism within schools, organizations, and communities. Finally, there need be laws, such as those enforced by the Civil Rights Commission, to ensure that Chinese immigrants, like all other U.S. citizens, are indeed treated equally and fairly in all areas of life. An important message of this article is that the career barriers faced by Chinese immigrants are multilevel and multifaceted.

Fitzgerald’s use of irony not only articulates Gatsby’s internal conflict but also reflects a broader, detailed analysis of 1920s American culture. The novel’s society is mired in paradoxes: vast, lively parties offer a veneer of communal joy, yet individuals find themselves ensnared in webs of loneliness and isolation — an idea earlier distilled in the antithesis of “large parties are so intimate.” Just as sprawling celebrations are ironically the settings for personal alienation, Gatsby’s grandiose dream results in a hauntingly vacuous reality. Thus, irony becomes a vital literary instrument in Fitzgerald’s repertoire, enabling him to accentuate the disparity between appearance and essence, weaving a narrative rich in depth and commentary. It lays bare the era’s cultural ethos, where individuals are perpetually navigating the dissonance between the American Dream’s lustrous facade and its deeply flawed, often sorrowful incarnation.

In "The Great Gatsby," Fitzgerald deftly captures not just the personal struggles of Gatsby himself, but paints a vivid canvas of the 1920s in America. He shows us a world caught in contradictions: the grand and noisy parties give off the illusion of shared happiness, but peel back the layers and you'll find people trapped in their own private worlds of solitude. It's like when Fitzgerald says big parties have an unexpected intimacy—it's the perfect contrast showing us the truth behind the façade. As these epic celebrations serve as backdrops for feelings of disconnect, Gatsby’s own magnificent aspirations crumble into an empty pit of reality. Irony, for Fitzgerald, isn't just a tool; it's the brush he uses to highlight the gap between what seems to be and what truly is, stitching together a story with real depth and social critique. This tactic starkly exposes the cultural mindset of the time: people endlessly trying to reconcile the shiny, attractive image of the American Dream with its deeply embedded imperfections and often heartache-filled real-life counterpoint.

Based on the two news summaries provided, it is evident that the "Good Ones" summary is better than the "Bad Ones" summary. The reasons why the "Good Ones" summary is better are as follows:

1. Comprehensive Coverage: The "Good Ones" summary covers multiple news items, including the US macro data, Fitch downgrade of the US, Macau's gaming revenue, and China's EV sales. This breadth of coverage provides a holistic view of different sectors and regions, offering readers a more complete understanding of the current events.

2. In-depth Information: The "Good Ones" summary provides specific details and figures to support the news. For instance, it mentions the ISM manufacturing index, employment figures, job openings, as well as specific numbers related to Macau's gaming industry and EV sales. This level of detail makes the news more informative and engaging for the readers.

3. Context and Analysis: The "Good Ones" summary incorporates contextual information and analysis to give readers a better understanding of the news. For example, it mentions the reasons behind the Fitch downgrade of the US, highlights the performance drivers in Macau's gaming industry, and discusses the positive signs in the EV sector. This analysis helps readers interpret the news and its implications correctly.

Guidelines for Writing News Summaries:

1. Be comprehensive: Include all relevant news items within a specific context or theme. This helps readers grasp the bigger picture and understand the interconnectedness of different events.

2. Provide factual details: Include specific figures, statistics, and data to support the news. This adds credibility to the summary and allows readers to verify the information if needed.

3. Add analysis and context: Provide additional information or analysis to help readers understand the implications or significance of the news. This adds value and depth to the summary, allowing readers to form a well-informed opinion.

4. Be concise: Summarize news items succinctly without sacrificing clarity. Focus on the key points and use precise language to convey the essential information effectively.

5. Be objective: Present the news in an unbiased manner, avoiding personal opinions or subjective language. Stick to the facts and let the readers draw their own conclusions from the information provided.

By adhering to these guidelines, news summaries can become informative, engaging, and valuable resources for readers seeking a quick overview of current events.
can you sum up the important elements of writing news summary

Certainly! Here are the important elements to consider when writing a news summary:

1. Conciseness: Summarize the news using clear and concise language. Focus on conveying key information without unnecessary detail or repetition.

2. Relevance: Include only the most important and relevant details of the news. Understand the central theme or topic and select information that directly contributes to the understanding of that topic.

3. Objectivity: Maintain an objective and neutral tone. Present the facts without personal bias or subjective opinions.

4. Accuracy: Ensure the accuracy of the information presented in the summary. Verify facts and cross-reference multiple sources if necessary.

5. Clarity: Use straightforward and easily understandable language. Avoid jargon or technical terms unless they are essential to the understanding of the news.

6. Context: Provide relevant background information or context to aid readers in understanding the news. Explain the significance or implications of the events whenever possible.

7. Structure: Organize the news summary in a logical and coherent manner. Start with a clear headline or introduction, followed by the main points or key details, and conclude with a concise summary or takeaway.

8. Balance: Strive for balance by representing different perspectives or sides of the story, if applicable. Present a fair and comprehensive view of the news.

9. Credibility: Attribute information to reliable sources and cite them appropriately. Use reputable sources to enhance the credibility of the news summary.

10. Engagement: Aim to engage readers with informative and interesting content. Use compelling language and storytelling techniques, when appropriate, to grab readers' attention and maintain their interest.

By incorporating these elements into your news summaries, you can ensure that they are informative, accurate, and engaging, providing readers with a clear and concise understanding of the news.

(Bloomberg) --US factory activity contracted in July for a ninth-straight month, reflecting tepid demand for American merchandise at home and abroad.
The Institute for Supply Management’s gauge of factory activity edged up to 46.4 last month, according to data released Tuesday. Readings less than 50 indicate contraction, and the latest figure came in just below expectations.
Measures of new orders and production improved in July, with the former rebounding to a nine-month high. Even so, both remained in contractionary territory. The group’s gauge of exports, meanwhile, fell to its lowest level this year as outbound shipments of US goods continued to decline.


While other parts of the economy remain firm, high interest rates paired with an ongoing rotation in consumer preferences toward services have stifled the manufacturing sector. Sluggish demand abroad has proved to be an additional headwind.
Just two manufacturing industries — petroleum products and furniture — registered overall growth in July. Apparel, plastics and paper led the 16 industries that reported shrinking activity.

The broader labor market, however, remains strong. The government’s monthly jobs report, out Friday, is expected to show US employers added 200,000 jobs last month.

The Rif chain result from the African and Eurasian plates convergence, the closure of the Maghrebian, Ligurian, and Nevado Filabride Oceanic belts, and the subsequent collision between the African, Iberian, and Alkapeca microplate squeezed in between since the late Eocene (Platt et al.,2013; De Jong, 2003; Puga et al, 2011; Ruiz-Cruz et al., 2015; Santamaría-López et al. 2019; Marrone et al.,2020; Padrón-navarta et al.,2010) This collision was also responsible for the building and the accretion of the Betic–Maghrebide orogenic wedge and its radial westward and southward migration around the Gibraltar arc coevally with the opening andaccretion of the oceanic‐like crust of the Algerian‐Balearic basin since 16 Ma (e.g. Mauffret et al., 2004; Booth‐Rea et al., 2007; Platt et al.,2013; Giaconia et al., 2015). The latest collisional event should be triggered by the slab retreat and may had occurred since the late Miocene (Capella et al., 2018; Abbassi et al., 2020, 2022;  Beelen et al., 2020; 2022)(Fig.2a).

The Rif chain results from the convergence of the African and Eurasian plates, which led to the closure of the Maghrebian, Ligurian, and Nevado Filabride Oceanic belts. This, in turn, caused a collision between the African, Iberian, and Alkapeca microplates that were squeezed in between since the late Eocene (Platt et al., 2013; De Jong, 2003; Puga et al, 2011; Ruiz-Cruz et al., 2015; Santamaría-López et al. 2019; Marrone et al., 2020; Padrón-navarta et al., 2010). This collision was also responsible for the building and accretion of the Betic–Maghrebide orogenic wedge and its radial westward and southward migration around the Gibraltar arc coevally with the opening and accretion of the oceanic-like crust of the Algerian-Balearic basin since 16 Ma (e.g. Mauffret et al., 2004; Booth-Rea et al., 2007; Platt et al., 2013; Giaconia et al., 2015). The latest collisional event may have been triggered by the slab retreat and could have occurred since the late Miocene (Capella et al., 2018; Abbassi et al., 2020, 2022; Beelen et al., 2020; 2022) (see Fig. 2a).

Sure, here is a further enhanced version of the paragraph:

The Rif chain is the result of the convergence between the African and Eurasian plates that caused the closure of the Maghrebian, Ligurian, and Nevado Filabride Oceanic belts. This convergence created an immense pressure that led to the collision of the African, Iberian, and Alkapeca microplates. The collision started during the late Eocene period and was responsible for the formation and accretion of the Betic-Maghrebide orogenic wedge. Additionally, this process caused the wedge to radially shift westward and southward all around the Gibraltar arc. Coeval with this, the oceanic crust of the Algerian-Balearic basin started opening and accreting since 16 million years ago. Numerous studies have shown that the latest collisional event may have been triggered by slab retreat and possibly occurred during the late Miocene. The collision started during the late Eocene period and was responsible for the formation and accretion of the Betic-Maghrebide orogenic wedge (e.g., Platt et al., 2013; De Jong, 2003; Puga et al., 2011; Ruiz-Cruz et al., 2015; Santamaría-López et al., 2019; Marrone et al., 2020; Padrón-navarta et al., 2010). Additionally, this process caused the wedge to radially shift westward and southward all around the Gibraltar arc (e.g., Mauffret et al., 2004; Booth-Rea et al., 2007; Platt et al., 2013; Giaconia et al., 2015). Coeval with this, the oceanic crust of the Algerian-Balearic basin started opening and accreting since 16 million years ago (e.g., Mauffret et al., 2004; Platt et al., 2013; Giaconia et al., 2015). Numerous studies have shown that the latest collisional event may have been triggered by slab retreat and possibly occurred during the late Miocene. Some of the studies that support this theory include Capella et al. (2018), Abbassi et al. (2020, 2022), and Beelen et al. (2020, 2022). for a information retireval system, between 2 queries

Calculating the Jaccard Coefficient between two queries in an information retrieval system involves comparing the sets of documents retrieved by each query. Here's how you would do it step-by-step, followed by an application example.

### Steps to Calculate Jaccard Coefficient for Two Queries:

1. **Execute both queries**: Run both queries in the information retrieval system to get two sets of documents. Let’s call the set of documents retrieved by the first query `A`, and the set retrieved by the second query `B`.

2. **Identify intersecting documents**: Determine the set of documents that are common to both sets `A` and `B`. This is the intersection set, usually denoted as `A ∩ B`.

3. **Compute the union of documents**: Identify all unique documents that are retrieved by either query. This forms the union of sets `A` and `B`, denoted as `A ∪ B`.

4. **Calculate the Jaccard Coefficient**: The Jaccard Coefficient is calculated using the following formula:

\[ J(A, B) = \frac{|A ∩ B|}{|A ∪ B|} \]

where `|A ∩ B|` is the number of documents in the intersection and `|A ∪ B|` is the number of documents in the union.

### Application Example:

Imagine that Query 1 (`Q1`) retrieves documents `[D1, D2, D3]`, and Query 2 (`Q2`) retrieves `[D2, D3, D4, D5]`.

1. **Sets for each query**:
   - Set A: {D1, D2, D3}
   - Set B: {D2, D3, D4, D5}

2. **Intersection of A and B**:
   - A ∩ B: {D2, D3}

3. **Union of A and B**:
   - A ∪ B: {D1, D2, D3, D4, D5}

4. **Calculate the Jaccard Coefficient**:
   - J(A, B) = |A ∩ B| / |A ∪ B| = 2 / 5 = 0.4

The Jaccard Coefficient for these two queries is 0.4, indicating that 40% of the retrieved documents are shared between the two queries. This measure could be used to understand the similarity between the queries in terms of their retrieved results. A higher Jaccard Coefficient would imply a greater overlap and thus higher similarity between the queries.
ask me a challenging qustion about it

Certainly! Here’s a challenging question that integrates the concept of Jaccard Coefficient with some statistical thinking and understanding of information retrieval nuances:

Given an information retrieval system with a large and diverse dataset, can you discuss how the Jaccard Coefficient’s value might be influenced by the frequency distribution of terms within the documents? Specifically, please explore how common terms (high document frequency) versus rare terms (low document frequency) in the queries might affect the similarity measurement provided by the Jaccard Coefficient, and how this might impact the interpretation of query similarity in such contexts.
jaccard only looks at the dataset as a unique dataset so the frequency won't make a difference in calculating the similarity

That's correct; the Jaccard Coefficient treats sets as collections of unique elements, so the frequency of terms within the documents does not directly affect its calculation. However, the choice of terms included in the queries can influence the resulting document sets and thus the calculated Jaccard similarity. Here's how:

- **Common terms (high document frequency)**: If both queries contain terms that are very common across the document corpus, they are likely to retrieve a larger number of documents, including many that are not particularly relevant to the specific information need. This can inflate the size of both the intersection and the union, potentially leading to a Jaccard Coefficient that suggests a higher similarity due to the prevalence of these common terms, rather than a meaningful thematic or topical similarity.

- **Rare terms (low document frequency)**: Conversely, if the queries contain rare terms that only appear in a few highly relevant documents, the resulting retrieved sets may be smaller and more focused. This can lead to a Jaccard Coefficient that is lower if the rare terms do not overlap, or higher if they do, thus potentially providing a more accurate measure of the actual similarity between the queries' intents.

In practical information retrieval applications, variants of the basic Jaccard Coefficient or additional measures might be used to account for term frequency and other factors to provide a more nuanced similarity assessment. For example, the TF-IDF (Term Frequency-Inverse Document Frequency) weighting scheme could be used in conjunction with Jaccard similarity to give less weight to common terms and more weight to rare, relevant terms. This would provide a more discriminating measure of the similarity between the sets of documents returned by each query.

Despite potentially high Jaccard similarity due to these overlapping common terms, the actual intent or subject matter of the queries could be quite different. Thus, it is crucial to consider the context and distinctiveness of the document contents and query terms when interpreting the Jaccard Coefficient to ensure that it accurately reflects conceptual similarity rather than just term overlap.

Conceptually different queries could yield a high Jaccard Coefficient if the queries share a set of common terms that are frequent in the corpus, resulting in a large intersection relative to the overall union of retrieved documents. how length normalization is related to jaccard coefficient

Length normalization is not directly related to the Jaccard Coefficient, as the Jaccard Coefficient does not consider the length of documents or their term frequency – it only measures the similarity based on the presence or absence of unique terms. However, length normalization is important in information retrieval to prevent a bias toward longer documents. If two document sets differ significantly in length, and you're using a similarity measure that doesn't account for length, you might misinterpret the similarity score. In the context of Jaccard, this misinterpretation is unlikely, as it is inherently normalized by the sizes of the sets in its calculation.
How can I use length normalization to get a better jaccard coefficient

Length normalization does not directly modify the Jaccard Coefficient because the Jaccard Coefficient itself is a normalization method based on set sizes. However, to indirectly influence the Jaccard Coefficient with a consideration similar to length normalization, you could preprocess your data:

- **Pre-filtering**: Before applying the Jaccard Coefficient, filter out common terms with high document frequency (stop words) which can disproportionately affect the size of document sets, especially for longer documents.

- **Post-processing normalization**: Adjust the Jaccard Coefficient results by considering the lengths (or term counts) of the original documents.

These pre- and post-processing steps can help mitigate the effect of document length on the similarity measure, similar to how length normalization improves other metrics.
Ask me a question about calculating query match score with document using log frequency weighting
Could you describe the steps involved in calculating a query match score with a document using log frequency weighting and elaborate on how it differs from using raw term frequency?
I am studying log frequency weighting in ranked information retrieval ask me a question about it

How does the application of log frequency weighting in ranked information retrieval contribute to the discrimination of term importance compared to using raw term frequency, and what is the impact of this weighting on the ranking of documents with respect to a given query?
side question, how does it discrimitate though?

Log frequency weighting discriminates term importance by reducing the impact of term frequency's linear growth on document ranking. Unlike raw term frequency which increases proportionally with the number of term occurrences, log frequency weighting scales this growth logarithmically. Here's how it works:

1. **Less Sensitive to High Frequency**: Common terms that appear many times within a document (e.g., "the", "is", "of") would disproportionately inflate a document's relevance score if raw frequency was used. Log frequency weighting mitigates this by providing diminishing returns as term frequency increases, which means that each additional occurrence of a term contributes less to the score.

2. **Increased Discrimination**: By dampening the impact of high-frequency terms, log frequency weighting also increases the relative importance of medium- and low-frequency terms, which are often more indicative of a document's unique content.

Thus, the log frequency weighting helps ensure that a document containing a term many times does not dominate over documents that contain the term fewer times but might be more contextually relevant to the query. The impact on ranking is that it more accurately reflects the meaningful presence of terms within documents, improving the quality of search results in a ranked information retrieval system.

Of course reducing the linear impact of a term helps when we are comparing the search query with different lengths of documents. if we don't reduce it the longer and bigger documents will always get the higher rank

That's precisely the point. By using log frequency weighting, we prevent longer documents from automatically receiving higher relevance scores simply because they have more text and hence, potentially, more term occurrences. Log frequency weighting ensures that relevance is judged more on the presence of relevant terms and less on document length. This levels the playing field between longer and shorter documents, providing a more balanced and fair ranking mechanism in information retrieval systems.
