Holden Caulfield: The Eternal Teenage Icon

Across generations, J.D. Salinger's "The Catcher in the Rye" has maintained its grip on the American psyche, and much of this influence can be traced to the novel's enigmatic protagonist, Holden Caulfield. Through Holden, Salinger captures the essence of teenage angst and disillusionment in a way that resonates with readers long into adulthood. His candid, colloquial narrative takes us on a journey through his world, imparting deep-seated feelings of nostalgia, confusion, and the desire for a world untainted by the phoniness of adult life.

One could argue that Holden is the embodiment of eternal teenage rebellion. Even as we grow older and ostensibly wiser, there's something about his unfiltered perspective that resonates with the disaffected teenage soul that still lingers within each of us. Holden's rejection of societal norms and expectations, as well as his relentless pursuit for authenticity, offers a kind of cathartic escape for readers who may have grappled with similar feelings of alienation in their formative years.

Holden's familiar, relatable voice evokes a strong connection with readers, as he navigates the complexities of adolescence and shares his cutting observations about the world around him. His language, peppered with profanity and spontaneous musings, elicits a sense of honesty, which in turn makes him a reliable narrator in the eyes of the reader. Despite his often jaded outlook on life, Holden's vulnerability shines through, inviting us to empathize with his predicament and understand the forces that have shaped his outlook.

At its core, "The Catcher in the Rye" is a study of the elusive, transient nature of innocence and the arduous task of coming to terms with a world that is fraught with deception and phoniness. Holden's dream of becoming the "catcher in the rye," saving children from the harrowing plunge into adulthood, reveals his deep-seated fear of change and disillusionment. In this way, the novel speaks to the adolescent inside each of us—the one that yearns for a simpler, more authentic existence, far removed from the burdens and facades of adult life.

As we follow Holden's haphazard journey, we can't help but find solace in the fact that we are not alone in our struggles to make sense of the world and our place within it. In many ways, Holden is the voice of a generation—a timeless testament to the challenges that come with growing up, and a poignant reminder that the search for truth and authenticity extends far beyond the confines of our teenage years. Through the enduring legacy of "The Catcher in the Rye," we find comfort in the notion that, whether it be in the '50s or today, the spirit of Holden Caulfield lives on, a perpetual emblem of the disenchanted, the skeptical, and the eternally young at heart.

delve deeper into the first prompt

For the first prompt, a narrative essay could illustrate a moral dilemma in which a character must decide whether or not to do something unethical to achieve a worthy goal. 

The essay can start with introducing the character and the goal they are trying to achieve. Perhaps they are trying to find a cure for a rare disease that is affecting a family member or someone they care about deeply. However, they discover that the only way to test their new experimental drug is to conduct ethically questionable experiments on animals or even humans.

The character is faced with a difficult decision: do they use the new drug to cure the disease, potentially saving countless lives in the future, or do they hold on to their moral beliefs and refuse to use an experimental drug on innocent living beings?

Along the way, the essay can delve into the internal and external conflicts the character is facing. The character may struggle with guilt and shame, but also feel the pressure to achieve their goal of finding a cure and the pain of watching their loved ones suffer. Other characters in the story can also present conflicting views and offer different perspectives on the situation.

Ultimately, through their decision, the character must come to terms with the fact that the end does not always justify the means, and that there are other ways to achieve their goal without compromising their morals. The essay can end with a reflective thought, emphasizing that honorable and ethical behavior is essential, even in the face of difficult decisions and tempting shortcuts.

conversation.content: Write about Emily’s fantasy and obsession with BBC and how she brings that up to her college boyfriend

Emily had always been obsessed with the BBC. She loved the prestige, the elegance, and the sophistication that came with everything the British network produced. From documentaries to dramas, Emily was an avid viewer of it all.

But Emily's interest in the BBC wasn't just a casual appreciation; it was a full-blown fantasy. She longed to be a part of the network, to work alongside their brilliant minds and contribute to their incredible programming. Emily even found herself dreaming about the BBC at night, often waking up with a sense of longing for something that seemed out of reach.

Emily's obsession with the BBC was so consuming that she brought it up constantly to her college boyfriend, Adam. She would gush about their latest dramas, dissect every documentary, and explain why their news coverage was so much better than anything in the US. It was clear to Adam that Emily had a serious thing for the BBC, and while he found it a little odd, he didn't mind listening to her talk about it.

In fact, Adam began to realize that his girlfriend's passion for the BBC wasn't just a flight of fancy – it was something that truly drove her. He began to support Emily's dream of working for the network, encouraging her to pursue it in any way she could. And so, Emily threw herself into her studies, working hard to attain the skills she knew she would need to make her fantasy a reality.

Years later, after honing her craft and building connections in the industry, Emily finally landed a job with the very network she had dreamed about for so long. And as she settled into her new role, she couldn't help but feel grateful for the support and love of the person who had always believed in her – her college boyfriend Adam.

Even though Mr. Bennet doubts that Elizabeth loves Mr. Darcy, at first, he consents to let the two be married. Why does he say he does this? 
Why are both Elizabeth and Mr. Darcy happy to see and welcome Mr. and Mrs. Gardiner into their home?

1. Mr. Bennet initially doubted Elizabeth's love for Mr. Darcy, but he ultimately consents to their marriage because he is convinced of Mr. Darcy's good character and genuine affection for Elizabeth. He realizes that Mr. Darcy is not the same person he thought him to be and that he had acted foolishly in preventing their marriage earlier. When Elizabeth tells him that she has accepted Mr. Darcy's proposal, Mr. Bennet is happy for her and trusts her judgment. He says that he had been blind and misguided in his previous perception of Mr. Darcy, and he now sees him as a suitable husband for his daughter.

2. Both Elizabeth and Mr. Darcy are happy to welcome Mr. and Mrs. Gardiner into their home because they have played an important role in bringing the two of them together. Mr. Gardiner had encouraged Elizabeth to consider Mr. Darcy's proposal and had helped her to realize her own feelings for him. Meanwhile, Mrs. Gardiner had been a supportive confidante to Elizabeth during her difficult moments. Thus, their presence symbolizes the positive impact they have had on the couple's lives and marks an important reunion for them all. Additionally, Mr. and Mrs. Gardiner are respected members of Elizabeth's family, so their approval of the marriage is particularly meaningful to Elizabeth and Mr. Darcy.

The overall weight change would significantly depend on advancements in battery technology, aiming for higher energy density and lighter weight. To replace the four variants of smart quotes with the standard two variants of double and single quotes in gVim, you can use the following regular expression:

:%s/[“‘’”]/=submatch(0) == ‘“’ ? ‘”’ : “’”/g

This regex pattern uses the :s command in gVim to perform a substitution. The pattern [“‘’”] matches any of the four smart quote variants.

The =submatch(0) == ‘“’ ? '”’ : “'” expression in the replacement pattern checks if the matched text is equal to a left double quote (“). If it is, it replaces it with a double quote (“), otherwise with a single quote (').

To execute this regex pattern, you can follow these steps in gVim:
1. Open your file in gVim.
2. Press Esc to enter command mode.
3. Enter :%s/[“‘’”]/=submatch(0) == ‘“’ ? '”’ : “'”/g to perform the substitution.
4. Press Enter to execute the command and replace the smart quotes.

how can I drag / place the sublime’s Build Results panel into the certain cell of layout grid, or undock it?

I'm sorry for any confusion earlier. By default, the Build Results panel in Sublime Text is docked and cannot be undocked. However, there is a package called "MoveTab" that can allow you to move the Build Results panel to a new tab or even to a new window. Here's how you can do it:

1. Install the "MoveTab" package via Package Control by going to Preferences > Package Control and searching for "MoveTab."

2. Once the package is installed, open the Build Results panel by selecting Tools > Build Results > Show Build Results.

3. Right-click on the Build Results tab at the bottom of the Sublime Text window and select "Move to new tab" or "Move to new window" to move the panel to a new tab or window.

4. You can then drag and drop the new tab or window into the position that you want in the layout grid.

Note that this method may not work for everyone, depending on your version of Sublime Text and the MoveTab package. Additionally, keep in mind that moving the Build Results panel to a new tab or window may disrupt your workflow if you are used to having it docked in the default position.

how would I make bold text?

To make text bold in Markdown, you can use asterisks (*) or underscores (_). Here are two examples:

- **Bold** text using asterisks: `**Bold**`
- __Bold__ text using underscores: `__Bold__`

So if you want to make a specific text bold, you simply need to add either two asterisks or two underscores before and after that text.

so is it like this: __Bold__

Using two underscore symbols before and after a piece of text will render that text in bold in Markdown. 

For example, if you write `__Bold__`, it will appear as **Bold** in the rendered output.

yeah it does! Wait, then how did you make normal double underscores?

To display a single underscore in Markdown, you can use the backslash (\) character to "escape" the formatting syntax. 

For example, if you write `\_`, it will display as an underscore in the output. 

So, to display the text "__Bold__" without actually making it bold, you can use the backslash character to escape the underscores like this: `\_\_Bold\_\_`.

English
provide a Markdown cheatsheet.

conversation.content: could you please make me a MarkDown cheatsheet?

Sure! Here's a MarkDown cheatsheet:

# Headers
Use the pound symbol (#) for headers, with one pound sign for the largest headers, and six for the smallest.

# Largest Header
## Second Largest Header
### Third Largest Header
#### Fourth Largest Header
##### Fifth Largest Header
###### Smallest Header

# Emphasis
Use asterisks or underscores to add emphasis to text:

*Italic text*
_Italic text_
**Bold text**
__Bold text__
**Bold and _italic_ text**
~~Strikethrough text~~

# Lists
Use hyphens, plus signs, or asterisks to make unordered lists. To make ordered lists, simply number each item:

- Item 1
- Item 2
- Item 3

+ Item 1
+ Item 2
+ Item 3

* Item 1
* Item 2
* Item 3

1. First item
2. Second item
3. Third item

# Links
To add links, use square brackets for the text and parentheses for the URL:

[Link text](URL)

# Images
To add images, use an exclamation point before the square brackets:

![Alt text](Image URL)

# Code
Use single backticks (`) for inline code, and triple backticks for code blocks:
```
function test() {
  console.log("Hello World!");
}
```

# Blockquotes
Use the greater than sign for blockquotes:

> Quote text

# Horizontal Rule
To add a horizontal rule, use three hyphens, asterisks, or underscores on a new line:

---

* * *

___

That's it! Hope it helps!
wait, how do I make bold text again?

To make text bold in Markdown, you can use either two asterisks `**` or two underscores `__` at the beginning and end of the text. For example:

**This text will be bold**
__This text will also be bold__

Both will output: **This text will be bold**

GB020	Are there definite or specific articles?	An article is a marker that accompanies the noun and expresses notions such as (non-)specificity and (in)definiteness. Sometimes these notions of specificity and definiteness are summed up in the term 'identifiability'. The formal expression is irrelevant; articles can be free, bound, or marked by suprasegmental markers such as tone. Articles are different from demonstratives in that demonstratives occur in a paradigm of markers that have a clear spatial deictic function. As demonstratives can grammaticalize into definite or specific articles, they form a natural continuum, making it hard to define discrete categories, but to qualify as an article a marker should be used in some cases to express definiteness without also expressing a spatial deictic meaning.
GB021	Do indefinite/non-specific nominals commonly have indefinite/non-specific articles?	For this feature, we need explicit support that indefinite/non-specific NPs commonly occur with an indefinite/non-specific article. Three or more examples of indefinite/non-specific nominals occurring with an indefinite/non-specific article is sufficient to code 1.  An indefinite article is a marker that accompanies the indefinite noun and expresses notions such as non-specificity and indefiniteness. Sometimes these notions of non-specificity and indefiniteness are summed up in the term ‘identifiability’. A language does not necessarily have both a non-specific/indefinite and a specific/definite marker. These markers often stem from very different sources (numerals and demonstratives) and need not be similar in formal expression or position.  The formal expression is irrelevant; articles can be free, bound, or marked by suprasegmental markers such as tone. Articles are different from demonstratives in that demonstratives occur in a paradigm of markers that have a clear spatial deictic function. As demonstratives can grammaticalize into definite or specific articles, they form a natural continuum, making it hard to define discrete categories. Articles are more grammaticalized, i.e. are often [obligatory](https://github.com/grambank/grambank/wiki/Obligatoriness) in certain contexts that require definite or specific reference. Definite or specific articles can also grammaticalize from pronouns meaning ‘a certain’. As articles necessarily accompany nouns, it is in these cases that it is necessary to investigate whether the marker can occur independently or not; if it can it is most likely a pronoun and not an article. Articles can be homophonous with pronouns and demonstratives, and also with classifiers.
GB022	Are there prenominal articles?	All questions concerning the order of elements aim to capture a pragmatically unmarked order. If both GB022 and GB023 are coded 1, please write a comment. Articles cover both definite or indefinite articles as defined in [GB020](https://github.com/grambank/grambank/wiki/GB020) and [GB021](https://github.com/grambank/grambank/wiki/GB021) respectively. In order to answer 1 for this feature, the markers' functions need to meet one of those definitions, so 1 should also have been answered for [GB020](https://github.com/grambank/grambank/wiki/GB020) or [GB021](https://github.com/grambank/grambank/wiki/GB021).
GB023	Are there postnominal articles?	All questions concerning the order of elements aim to capture a pragmatically unmarked order.If both GB022 and GB023 are coded 1, please write a comment. Articles cover both definite or indefinite articles as defined in [GB020](https://github.com/grambank/grambank/wiki/GB020) and [GB021](https://github.com/grambank/grambank/wiki/GB021) respectively. In order to answer 1 for this feature, the markers' functions need to meet one of those definitions, so 1 should also have been answered for [GB020](https://github.com/grambank/grambank/wiki/GB020) or [GB021](https://github.com/grambank/grambank/wiki/GB021).
GB026	Can adnominal property words occur discontinuously?	This feature describes an adnominal property word denoting core adjectival concepts such as shape, value, dimension, age, color (at a minimum -- many other meanings are possible) which can be separated from the noun it modifies by some element that is not part of the nominal phrase. For example, can you say ***the man** is running **big*** to mean ‘**the big man** is running’?  Typically a language which allows this has extensive [agreement](https://github.com/grambank/grambank/wiki/Agreement) systems so that you can still work out what modifies what in the NP without them being adjacent (e.g. the ‘Australian type’). NPs that are made up of several coordinated NPs that can be interpreted by the verb or other elements are not relevant here. This features aims specifically to capture the phenomenon of a single NP whose property words can occur outside of and not immediately adjacent to the portion of the NP that contains the head. Examples of the type *I painted the house red* or *I saw the boy big* are not necessarily discontinuous, but most likely resultative or contrastive (*I saw the boy big* [as opposed to before when he was small]). These should be disregarded for the purposes of this feature.  Note that for the purposes of this feature only property words (e.g. *tall*, *red*, *friendly*) should be considered. Any other elements described as 'adjectives' or 'adjectival' in the grammatical description (e.g. quantifiers, demonstratives) should be disregarded in coding this feature.
GB027	Are nominal conjunction and comitative expressed by different elements?	Is there a difference between the marking of NP coordination (*John **and** Mary went to market.*) and the marking of comitative phrases (*John **with** Mary went to market.*)? In some languages the only way to coordinate noun phrases is with a comitative phrase, i.e. the only way to say ‘X **and** Y’ is ‘X **with** Y’. To see whether an element is comitative or coordinating you can check case marking and agreement. For example, if X is the element in question and in the dative you get ‘John-DAT X Mary-DAT’, then X is likely coordinating. If you get ‘John-DAT X Mary’, X is likely comitative. If there is agreement, if you get ‘John X Mary verb-PL’ rather than 'John X Mary verb-SG' (just like ‘John X suitcase verb-SG’), this suggests that X is coordinating.
GB028	Is there a distinction between inclusive and exclusive?	Is there a pronoun or other marker that explicitly marks the inclusion of an interlocutor? This feature is not restricted to the pronominal system but includes person [indexing](https://github.com/grambank/grambank/wiki/Indexing-vs.-pronouns) as well. If inclusive is marked overtly in either the pronominal system or through verbal marking this is sufficient to trigger a 1 for this feature, even if exclusive has no overt morphological marking.
GB030	Is there a gender distinction in phonologically independent third person pronouns?	This question targets the existence of any [gender distinction](https://github.com/grambank/grambank/wiki/Noun-Classes-and-Classifiers) in [phonologically independent third person pronouns](https://github.com/grambank/grambank/wiki/Indexing-vs.-pronouns). For the purposes of this feature we define third person pronouns as including demonstratives. A masculine/feminine distinction is commonly encoded in third person pronouns, but distinctions in any other noun class/gender categories such as animacy also satisfy the criterion for coding a 1 for this feature. For languages with no third person independent pronouns or no noun class/gender distinctions in third person pronouns, a gender distinction in demonstratives would be sufficient to trigger a 1 here. If pronouns with just inanimate referents (or alternatively, just animate referents) agree with the noun class/gender of the corresponding noun that also suffices for 1. If a language has any gender distinction for third person pronouns but not for demonstratives, this is also sufficient for a 1. For more information on the difference between grammatical gender and social, cultural, and biological constructs or traits, see the [gender wiki page](https://github.com/grambank/grambank/wiki/Grammatical-gender-and-other-notions-of-gender).
GB031	Is there a dual or unit augmented form (in addition to plural or augmented) for all person categories in the pronoun or person index system?	A dual or unit augmented form must be present throughout the paradigm (i.e. for all person categories) for this feature to be coded as 1. Both [independent pronouns and bound person indexes](https://github.com/grambank/grambank/wiki/Indexing-vs.-pronouns) are to be considered in coding this feature. Inclusive and exclusive categories of first person are not considered separate person categories for the purposes of coding this feature (e.g. if a language has dual number in third, second, and any first person category it is sufficient for triggering a 1). A dual or unit augmented form for a single person category in the paradigm is *not* sufficient for a 1 code.
GB035	Are there three or more distance contrasts in adnominal demonstratives?	Demonstratives are modifiers that can modify nouns (of any type and not just a restricted set such as location nouns) to mark position (e.g. deixis or reference within discourse). This doesn't have to be only Euclidean distance (meters, inches etc.), it could also be concerned with near or far in relation to the interlocutors (cf. Wolof). If the system of adnominal demonstratives includes an anaphoric demonstrative this does not count as a third distance.

GB020: In Paraguayan Guarani, there are no definite or specific articles. The language lacks markers that accompany nouns to express notions of specificity, definiteness, or identifiability.

GB021: Paraguayan Guarani does not have indefinite/non-specific articles. There are no markers accompanying indefinite/non-specific nouns to express non-specificity or indefiniteness.

GB022: Paraguayan Guarani does not have prenominal articles. There are no articles occurring before the noun in the language.

GB023: Paraguayan Guarani does not have postnominal articles. There are no articles occurring after the noun in the language.

GB026: Paraguayan Guarani does not allow adnominal property words to occur discontinuously. Property words cannot be separated from the noun they modify by other elements.

GB027: Paraguayan Guarani does not distinguish between nominal conjunction and comitative with different elements. The marking for noun phrase coordination and comitative phrases is the same.

GB028: Paraguayan Guarani does not have a distinction between inclusive and exclusive in its pronominal system or person indexing.

GB030: Paraguayan Guarani does not have a gender distinction in phonologically independent third person pronouns. There is no gender distinction encoded in third person pronouns or demonstratives.

GB031: Paraguayan Guarani does not have a dual or unit augmented form for all person categories in its pronoun or person index system. There is no dual or unit augmented form present throughout the paradigm.

GB035: Paraguayan Guarani does not have three or more distance contrasts in adnominal demonstratives. The language lacks a system of demonstratives that mark multiple distance contrasts.

New HK Morning Meetings Agenda
Dear all,
We run morning meetings to equip RMs and ICs with the information, ideas, enablers to help clients and generate results.
We’re always looking for ways to improve these so they fulfil their purpose.
Recently, we’ve been gathering feedback on the current Morning Meetings and as a result are proposing some changes to the current schedule and content.
We’re doing this in close partnership between IWS and the RM/IC leadership teams to meet the audience needs and make the meetings more objective and impactful.
These changes will start next week (week commencing 18th September).
What will change?
Schedule:
(1) There will be an RM focused Morning Meeting on Tuesday and an IC focused Morning Meeting on Wednesday
(2) The Friday Morning Meeting will become a thematic session with internal and external guest speakers
Content:
(3) Senior management messaging
(4) More focused topics/ideas for the specific audience
(5) High conviction ideas and extended coverage to all products
(6) Consistent follow-ups on closing out ideas and/or assessing performance
(7) Opportunities for Q&A
We look forward to your support and engagement, and please share any feedback on how we can continue to improve these sessions and make them valuable for you.
Sami Abouzahr

Bryce Wan

[Discretionary] Summary of PM Updates (Sep 13th)
Fixed Income – IG
We see a rebound in inflation data as well as oil and food prices in the US and other countries including Asia.
Market is expecting August CPI data to accelerate back to July’s level.
For US treasuries, given higher inflation data and the Jackson Hole signaling a hawkish bias, treasury yields have been above 4%, hovering at around 4.25% range.
Credit spread performance is still very resilient in the IG space despite the September seasonality (more issuances after summer vacation).
Asia IG tightened 4bp MTD, whilst US IG spread is kind of flattish.
Demand for high quality IG bonds are quite sufficient as well given the high and attractive carry to absorb the new supply.
Within Asia, we see high quality issuances from Korea and decent demand despite the already-tight spread and sticky inflows.
STB / Short-dated bond strategy
Adding to quality names and diversifying out of Asia (China in particular) into other regions in a gradual manner, as there is no imminent credit risk in our China holdings.
Looking to add attractive new issuances and utilize cash to lock in attractive carry in the market given the elevated yield.
Short dated bonds volatility remains low with duration at 1.9 years.
HYB
We see steady stabilization after sales figures rapidly jumped upon China’s policy announcement, followed by a fast fade-out with sales numbers down slightly last weekend, implying more stimulation might be needed to sustain the momentum.
Top-tier SOE developers take the lead with better sales figures, which match with our expectations of a “winners take all” market where stronger property developers outperform its weaker peers.
Continue to prefer SOE names. To continue to monitor the market on whether momentum can sustain. Currently expecting a L-shaped recovery in the coming 6-12 months.
Performance is relatively stable, most contributed from carry.
YTD down 1%, slightly recovered some loss from August (YTD -3% as of end-Aug). Positioning-wise, have sold some positions in India and Middle-East, but the overall risk nature has not changed and is comfortable with the current holdings.
REI
Overall market declined in Aug due to concerns over interest rate and HK-China issues
REI was down in August but has outperformed the benchmark by nearly 2%.
Australia contributed most positively. The Australian market was weak in view of renewed concerns of a “higher-for-longer” rate environment. From asset allocation perspective, our Underweight in Australia has thus contributed positively to our performance. On the stock selection front, our off-benchmark holding of an Australian logistic name, Goodman Group, has delivered a very strong performance which has also helped with its outperformance.
Our stock selection in Philippines contributed positively as well.
Hong Kong is the biggest detractor, mainly due to our holdings of retail landlords and Chinese tourists not spending as much as they did pre-Covid.
We took partial profit from our Philippines holding (Ayala Land) and rotated to Thailand (Central Pattana) due to its much stabler political landscape after the election. We also took profit in the market rally in August and reduced China exposure (Longfor Group), rotating into Singapore names such as Keppel DC REIT which are key beneficiaries as rates peak.
CK Asset remain as our top holding due to its strong balance sheet and defensiveness, followed by Goodman Group.
In terms of positioning, Singapore has the biggest absolute and relative weight in our portfolio. We are underweighting Hong Kong, China and Australia. We like Emerging Markets and are Overweight on Thailand and Indonesia.
Subsector-wise, we continue to be cautious on office while maintaining slight exposure in India due to its slightly better situation. We continue to like logistics, data centers as well as hotel resorts.
HD
In August, the strategy was down and underperformed the benchmark by
Taiwan was the better performing market in August whilst South Korea and Hong Kong underperformed, with Hong Kong having experienced one of the worst performances since February.
Sector-wise, real estate was the worst performing sector, with the drag mainly attributed by the retail landlords in Hong Kong. We do not hold any stocks of China property developers in this strategy. Financials is one of the key contributing sector due to our Underweight in Chinese banks. Energy have also contributed positively due to the strong oil prices.
Country-wise, Thailand was one of the best-performing markets due to the improved sentiment.
We reduced China exposure in property-related names, added to Taiwanese AI-related names, as well as rotated into Thailand due to the improved sentiment post-election.
In terms of positioning, we continue to Overweight Hong Kong and Singapore. In terms of relative sector weight, we have the biggest Overweight in IT and we continue to be Underweight in financials and materials.
AES
In August, the strategy was down 6.7%, outperforming the BM by around 60bps.
In general, our outperformance in August is mostly contributed by our Underweight in China and our focus on bottom-up stock picking. Although some of our China holdings such as Ping An and BYD have dragged the performance, PDD has contributed positively with its earnings beating market estimates. We continue to focus on companies in China with stable earnings and less pressure on cut in sales guidance, such as Wuxi AppTec, Baidu and Meituan which have reported strong results and shown resilient earnings recently.
Taiwan e-paper technology leader, E-Ink, has recently cut their 2023 sales guidance, hence the stock has underperformed this month within our Taiwan picks. We have added positions in other technology names such as Wiwynn and Unimicron due to the industry’s positive outlook.
Our Overweight in Indonesia with positive stock selection (banking sector in particular) has also contributed to the outperformance.
Within ASEAN and India, we continue to be positive but have finetuned our holdings, by taking profit on Bank Mandiri and adding exposure to Bank Rakyat Indonesia.
Within Hong Kong, we have exited HKEX due to weak trading volume and lack of catalysts.
ANGL
In August, the strategy was down -6.7% but has outperformed the benchmark by around 60bp. The strategy’s past months of outperformance has narrowed down the YTD relative underperformance compared with the benchmark.
Both PDD and Miniso have significantly beaten earnings expectations, due to the robust business growth in their sector targeting the mass market with its products at lower price points, as well as their expanding market share in their merchandise category.
In Taiwan, technology continue to hold up its performance in August. Our Taiwan technology holding (E-ink) was a detractor upon cutting its 2023 sales guidance. Some of our Chinese holdings such as BYD has also dragged our performance.
In terms of thematic exposure, we continue to maintain exposure to technology and are positive on major trends such as AI, with a focus on high-end ABF and semi-equipment names.
In terms of country exposure, we are Underweight in Hong Kong and China, and positive on Taiwan although we have done some rotation taking profits on certain names which have outperformed a lot, such as AICHIP. We also continue to build exposure in Japan in the semi-equipment segment.
CES
In August, the strategy has strongly outperformed the benchmark by 2.4%, mainly contributed by our stock selections in energy and consumer discretionary segments.
Our Overweight in internet names and communication services have contributed positively, while our position in more defensive SOE names in telecommunications have also outperformed the broader market. On the other hand, our Overweight in banks and financials have detracted.
We have sold positions in value holdings such as construction and railway companies as we are positioning to rotate to growth. We have also trimmed down names with less catalysts for the remaining year and bought internet names like Alibaba.
CES is the best performing Chinese Equity Fund on HSBC platform.
Some of the reasons for our outperformance against other Chinese equity funds and the broader market may include:
i) Compared to CES, the considerably large size of other competitors funds make it more difficult for the asset managers to switch investment styles given the market volatility;
ii) Many other asset managers are not allowed to trade U.S. Executive Order restricted companies, whilst our investment in some of the names under the Order in Telecom, Energy and Construction sectors have generated strong positive returns, thus offering a more flexible approach with better downside protection;
iii) Some managers are too aggressive in their positioning in consumption and healthcare names, which we have been Underweight in, leading to our strong outperformance against peers.

Security and Related Activities Control Act 1996:
    • Section 12: Term used: A security officer is a person who for remuneration watches, guards or protects any property. 
      
    • Section 26: Possession of batons:

Except as provided in this section, a security officer’s licence does not authorise the holder to be in possession of a baton while engaged in activities authorised by the licence.


    • Section 35: Term used: crowd controller

A crowd controller is a person who in respect of any licensed premises, place of entertainment, or public or private event or function, as part of his or her regular duties, performs for remuneration any function of — (a) controlling or monitoring the behaviour of persons; (b) screening persons seeking entry; or (c) removing persons for behavioural reasons, or any other prescribed function.

Criminal Code and Compilation Act 1913:
    • Section 70A: Trespass (the actual offence)

trespass on a place, means — (a) to enter or be in the place without the consent or licence of the owner, occupier or person having control or management of the place; or (b) to remain in the place after being requested by a person in authority to leave the place; or (c) to remain in a part of the place after being requested by a person in authority to leave that part of the place. (2) A person who, without lawful excuse, trespasses on a place commits an offence. Penalty for this subsection: imprisonment for 12 months and a fine of $12 000.

    • Section 260: Excessive force is unlawful

The SAR is influenced by sedimentary environments. Generally, climate conditions affect the sources, and tectonic activities usually affect the morphology of basins and the erosion strength (Chen et al., 2020). And sediments in depressed basins are symmetrically distributed in a circular pattern, while in rift basins, steep slope sources are more likely to reach the depocenter and form an asymmetric shape (Ma et al., 2022). From previously published studies, the SAR in the lacustrine basin ranges from 1.3 to 21.4 cm/kyr (Fig. 11 A). The SAR of the Ek2 in Cangdong Sag and Dongying Sag in the BBB is 21.4 cm/kyr and 19.2 cm/kyr, respectively, which are roughly the same. The SAR from the fourth and third members of the Shahejie Formation in Dongying Sag decrease slightly, and the well He-166 in the second member of the Shahejie Formation to the Dongying Formation decreased significantly, with a SAR of 9.9 cm/kyr (Liu et al., 2018). The SAR of well MY1 in the Fengcheng Formation of the Mahu Sag is 9.9 cm/kyr (Huang et al., 2023), this is somewhat different from the SAR of ~16 cm/kyr calculated by Huang et al. in 2021 for the FN7 well, which may be related to the differences in distance between the location of the drilling hole and depocenter. The SAR of the Xiagou Formation in the Jiuquan Basin and the Shulehe Formation in the Erlian Basin are 12.6 cm/kyr and 7.6 cm/kyr respectively (Chen et al., 2020; Yao et al., 2022). The sedimentation rate in the Ordos Basin is the lowest, with an average of 1.3 cm/kyr (Li et al., 2023; Wei et al., 2023). Compared with the ancient strata, the sediments in the modern lake have not experienced strong compaction or consolidation Diagenesis with higher SAR. The SAR of 175m continuous drilling and high-precision dating of Van Lake in Türkiye is 28 cm/kyr (Stockhecke et al., 2014). And the age-depth model shows that the curve slope gradually decreases with the increase of burial depth, which is most likely due to the compaction (Fig. 11B). The sediments of Jiangco, Maar and Sugan Lake in China for nearly 200 years, the SAR are 70 cm/kyr, 115cm/kyr and 169 cm/kyr, respectively, which were significantly higher than Van Lake (Fig. 11B) (Chu et al., 2009; Ji et al., 2021; Zhou et al., 2007).

scale of sentiment analysis

Sentiment analysis can be represented on different scales depending on the method and tool used. Here are some common sentiment analysis scales:

1. Binary Scale: This scale represents sentiment analysis with either a positive or negative polarity.

2. Ternary Scale: This scale divides sentiment analysis into three categories: positive, negative, and neutral.

3. Five-Point Scale: This scale measures sentiment analysis on a five-point scale: strong positive, mildly positive, neutral, mildly negative, and strongly negative.

4. Continuous Scale: This scale assigns a score on a continuous range from 0 (extremely negative) to 1 (extremely positive).

Failure to recognize that the American is at heart an idealist is to lack understanding of our national character. Two of our greatest interpreters proclaimed it, Emerson and William James. In a recent address at the Paris Sorbonne on "American Idealism," M. Firmin Roz observed that a people is rarely justly estimated by its contemporaries. The French, he says, have been celebrated chiefly for the skill of their chefs and their vaudeville actors, while in the disturbed 'speculum mundi' Americans have appeared as a collection of money grabbers whose philosophy is the dollar. It remained for the war to reveal the true nature of both peoples. The American colonists, M. Roz continues, unlike other colonists, were animated not by material motives, but by the desire to safeguard and realize an ideal; our inherent characteristic today is a belief in the virtue and power of ideas, of a national, indeed, of a universal, mission. In the Eighteenth Century we proposed a Philosophy and adopted a Constitution far in advance of the political practice of the day, and set up a government of which Europe predicted the early downfall. Nevertheless, thanks partly to good fortune, and to the farseeing wisdom of our early statesmen who perceived that the success of our experiment depended upon the maintenance of an isolation from European affairs, we established democracy as a practical form of government.


We have not always lived up to our beliefs in ideas. In our dealings with other nations, we yielded often to imperialistic ambitions and thus, to a certain extent, justified the cynicism of Europe. We took what we wanted—and more. From Spain we seized western Florida; the annexation of Texas and the subsequent war with Mexico are acts upon which we cannot look back with unmixed democratic pride; while more than once we professed a naive willingness to fight England in order to push our boundaries further north. We regarded the Monroe Doctrine as altruistic, while others smiled. But it suited England, and her sea power gave it force.
